nasute: <entryFree id="n30438" type="main" key="na_su_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāsūtē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. nasutus <sense id="n30438.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nasutus: <entryFree id="n30439" type="main" key="na_su_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāsūtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nasus</etym>, <sense id="n30439.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has a large nose, large-nosed</hi> (perh. not anteAug.). </sense><sense id="n30439.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">depygis, nasuta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus,</quote> <trans><tr>the elephant's trunk</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 10, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30439.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">sagacious, witty, satirical, censorious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nasutus nimium cupis videri: nasutum volo, nolo polyposum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:37:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 37, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 13, 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil nasutius est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:54:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 54, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo nasutissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Suas. 7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Suas. 7 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāsūtē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">satirically, scornfully, wittily, sarcastically</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu qui nasute scripta destringis mea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:4:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 4, 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nasute negare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:6:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 6, 5</bibl></cit> (dub.; al. vafre).</sense></entryFree>
nata: <entryFree id="n30440" type="main" key="na_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. natus, under <itype>nascor</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> B. 1.</entryFree>
natabilis: <entryFree id="n30441" type="main" key="na^ta_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nato</etym>, <sense id="n30441.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can swim</hi> or <hi rend="ital">float</hi> (post-class.): robur, Coripp. Laud. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:43" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 4, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natabulum: <entryFree id="n30442" type="main" key="na^ta_bu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătābŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30442.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a place for swimming, a swimming - place</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 353, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">natabula fluminis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Res Gest. Alex. 2:9" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Res Gest. Alex. 2, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
natabundus: <entryFree id="n30443" type="hapax" key="na^ta_bundus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătābundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n30443.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj., swimming</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Res Gest. Alex. M. 2:8" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Res Gest. Alex. M. 2, 8</bibl> (2, 31 Mai.).</sense></entryFree>
natal: <entryFree id="n30444" type="main" key="Natal"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Natal</orth> <etym> = natale, <hi rend="ital">birthday festival</hi></etym>, <sense id="n30444.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of one of the mimes of Laberius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in mimo, qui inscribitur Natal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:7:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 7, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
natalicius: <entryFree id="n30445" type="main" key="na_ta_li_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālīcĭus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. natalis</etym>, <sense id="n30445.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the hour</hi> or <hi rend="ital">day of one's birth, birthday, natal</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">qui haec Chaldaeorum natalicia praedicta defendunt,</quote> <trans><tr>a casting of nativities</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:42:89" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 42, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sidera,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 43, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dapes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:86:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 86, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lardum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:84" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sinciput,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 136</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:16" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies natalicius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:40:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 40, 20</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30445.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30445.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālīcĭ-um</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-tĭum</orth>), <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a birthday present</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid natalicii titulo tibi mittere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Censor.</author> de Die Nat. 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30445.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālīcĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. cena), <hi rend="ital">a birthday entertainment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hodie non descendit Antonius. Cur? Dat nataliciam in hortis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 6, 15</bibl></cit> (so acc. to Cod Vat.; others natalicia, as <gen>n.</gen> <number>plur.</number>).</sense></entryFree>
natalis: <entryFree id="n30446" type="main" key="na_ta_lis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>natus, nascor</etym>, <sense id="n30446.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to one's birth, birth-, natal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc emortualem facere ex natali die,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc huic lenonist hodie natalis dies,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natali die tuo scripsisti epistulam ad me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 5, 1</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quem ego diem vere natalem hujus urbis aut certe salutarem appellare possum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 40, 102</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natalis dies reditūs mei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:20:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 3, 20, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scit genius natale comes qui, temperat astrum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 187</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:797" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 797</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:219" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ib. 219</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:17:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 17, 19</bibl></cit>: humus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:9:78" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 9, 78</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:321" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 321</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sterilitas,</quote> <trans><tr>native</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 7</bibl></cit>: so, <cit><quote lang="la">natale decus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:61" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30446.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<case>abl.</case> natali; <cit><quote lang="la">rarely natale,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:391" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 391</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 775</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2534</bibl>; al. cf. Neue, Formenl. 1, p. 228 sq.), <gen>m.</gen> (sc. dies). </sense><sense id="n30446.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a birthday</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad urbem (veni) tertio Non. natali meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natales grate numeras?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 210</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus est natalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sex mihi natales ierant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Brutorum et Cassi natalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:37" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">debemus mehercule natales tuos perinde ac nostros celebrare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:30:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 30, 1</bibl></cit>. On this day it was customary to make offerings, the men to their Genius, and the women to Juno, and to make presents to each other, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:13:2" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 13, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:64:14" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 64, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30446.3" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">any anniversary, a commemorative festival</hi>.—Of <hi rend="ital">the day of the foundation of Rome</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">natali Urbis DCXXXII.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 4, 6, § 55</bibl></cit>.—(In eccl. Lat.) Of a martyr's death: dies in quo, lege functi carneā, in superna regna nascuntur Dei. <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Carm. 21, 171 sq.</bibl> So of other anniversaries, <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Ep. 20, 3</bibl>; Aug Serm. 15 de Sanct. <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Serm. 310</bibl> <hi rend="ital">in lemm.</hi>—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">natalem alicui eripere,</quote> <trans><tr>to prevent one's being born</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:390" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 390</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30446.4" n="B" level="2"> In <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātāles</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">birth, origin, lineage, extraction, descent, family</hi> (postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">natalium periti,</quote> <trans><tr>the casters of nativities</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:32:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 32, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cornelius Fuscus claris natalibus,</quote> <trans><tr>of distinguished birth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 86</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">natalium claritas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier natalibus clara,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:8:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 8, 18, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid, Catilina, tuis natalibus atque Cethegi Inveniet quisquam sublimius?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:231" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dedecus natalium velare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 21</bibl></cit>: natalibus suis restitui or reddi, <hi rend="ital">to be restored to one's birthright</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be</hi> <pb n="1189" /> <cb n="NATI" /> <hi rend="ital">freed from slavery</hi> (because all men were regarded as originally free), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:11:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 11, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertus natalibus redditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:2:3" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 38, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de restituendis natalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 73</bibl></cit> (78). —</sense><sense id="n30446.5" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of things, <hi rend="ital">birth, origin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adamanti pallor argenti, et in auro non nisi excellentissimo natales,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>is produced only in gold-mines</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 4, 15, § 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arborum,</quote> <trans><tr>the seed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 17, 10, 14, § 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natales impatientiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pat. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Pentateucho natales agnitionis supputabuntur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> adv. Marc. 1, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30446.6" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>: <cit><quote lang="la">et Musis natale in nemore Heliconis adsignant,</quote> <trans><tr>the place of birth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 7, 12, § 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30447" type="main" key="Na_ta_lis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nātālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30447.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, e. g. Antonius Natalis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:50:54 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 50, 54 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">71</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natalitius: <entryFree id="n30448" type="main" key="na_ta_li_tius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātālītius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. natalicius.</entryFree>
natans: <entryFree id="n30449" type="main" key="na^tans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. nato <sense id="n30449.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nataticius: <entryFree id="n30450" type="gloss" key="na^ta_tici^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātìcĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nato</etym>, <sense id="n30450.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can swim</hi>: nataticius, <foreign lang="greek">nhktiko/s</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
natatilis: <entryFree id="n30451" type="main" key="na^ta_ti^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30451.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can swim</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">animae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Herm. 33</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātĭles</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">swimming creatures</hi>: feras, volucres, reptiles, natatiles, Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 10, 332; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Mund. 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natatio: <entryFree id="n30452" type="main" key="na^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30452.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a swimming</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30452.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: habeant igitur sibi arma, sibi equos ... sibi pilam, sibi natationes atque cursus. * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 16, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">frigidae natationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n30452.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a place for swimming, swimming - place</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:27:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 27, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 1:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 1, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natator: <entryFree id="n30453" type="main" key="na^ta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30453.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a swimmer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=93" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 93</bibl> Müll.: pugnat in adversas ire natator aquas. <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 122</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:19:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 19, 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:10:497" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 10, 497</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natatorius: <entryFree id="n30454" type="main" key="na^ta_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>natator</etym>, <sense id="n30454.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a swimmer, that serves to swim with, natatory</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">cortex,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 17, 7, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30454.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātōrĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a place for swimming, a swimming - place, a bath; a pool</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vade ad natatoria Siloe,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Joh. 9, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natatura: <entryFree id="n30455" type="gloss" key="na^ta_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30455.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a place for swimming</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bathing</hi>: natatura, <foreign lang="greek">kolumbh/qra</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
natatus: <entryFree id="n30456" type="main" key="na^ta_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30456.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a swimming</hi> (postAug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:5:25" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 5, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">piscium natatu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 17, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluvios natatu scindere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 347</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rapt. Pros. 3, 333</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nates: <entryFree id="n30457" type="main" key="na^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătes</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, v. natis.</entryFree>
naticidium: <entryFree id="n30458" type="gloss" key="na_ti^ci_di^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātĭcīdĭum</orth> or ‡ <orth extent="full" lang="la">gnātĭcīdĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>natus-caedo</etym>, <sense id="n30458.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the murdering of one's son</hi> or <hi rend="ital">child, child-murder</hi>: gnaticidium, <foreign lang="greek">teknoktoni/a</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
natinatio: <entryFree id="n30459" type="gloss" key="na^ti^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătĭnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30459.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a being busy, business</hi>: natinatio dicebatur negotiatio et natinatores ex eo seditiosa negotia gerentes, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=166" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 166</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
natinator: <entryFree id="n30460" type="gloss" key="na^ti^na_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătĭnātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30460.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rebel;</hi> v. natinatio.</sense></entryFree>
natinor: <entryFree id="n30461" type="main" key="na^ti^nor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătĭnor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <sense id="n30461.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep., to be busy</hi>: audito tumultu Macedoniae Samnites, Lucanos inter se natinari atque factiosos esse, Cato ap. Paul. ex Fest. s. v. natinatio, p. 166 Müll.; v. h. v.</sense></entryFree>
natio: <entryFree id="n30462" type="main" key="na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nascor</etym>, <sense id="n30462.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a being born, birth;</hi> hence, transf. </sense><sense id="n30462.1" n="I" level="1"> Personified, Natio, <hi rend="ital">the goddess of birth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Natio quoque dea putanda est, quae, quia partus matronarum tueatur, a nascentibus Natio nominata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:18:47" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 18, 47</bibl></cit> (al. Nascio).— </sense><sense id="n30462.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A breed, stock, kind, species, race</hi> (rare but class.; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: genus, stirps, familia): in hominibus emendis si natione alter est melior, emimus pluris, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=93" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 93</bibl></cit> Müll.; <cit><quote lang="la">Auct. B. Alex. 7, 3: natio optimatium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:44:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 44, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">officiosissima candidatorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:23:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 23, 55</bibl></cit>.—Also in a contemptuous sense, <hi rend="ital">a race, tribe, set</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">salvete, fures maritimi, Famelica hominum natio, quid agitis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestra natio (Epicureorum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:29:74" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 29, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardelionum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 5, 1</bibl></cit>.—Of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">praegnantes opere levant: venter enim labore nationem reddit deteriorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:6:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 6, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=92" default="NO"><author>id.</author> L. L. 9, § 92</bibl> Müll.; and: in pecoribus quoque bonus proventus feturae bona natio dicitur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=167" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 167</bibl> Müll.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of things, <hi rend="ital">a sort, kind</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">nationes in apium naturā diximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 24, 50, § 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cera natione Pontica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 14, 49, § 83</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 25, 55, § 125</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30462.3" n="B" level="2"> In a more restricted sense, <hi rend="ital">a race of people</hi>, <cb n="NATO" /> <hi rend="ital">nation, people</hi> (used commonly in a more limited sense than gens, and sometimes as identical with it; cf.: gens, populus; usually applied by Cicero to distant and barbarous people): nam itast haec hominum natio; <cit><quote lang="la">in Epidamniis Voluptarii, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 1, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes nationes servitutem ferre possunt: nostra civitas non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:10:10:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 10, 10, 20</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">exteris nationibus ac gentibus ostendere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:11:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Font. 11, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne nationes quidem et gentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:39:93" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 39, 93</bibl></cit>; cf.<cit><quote lang="la">, in the reverse order: omnes exterae gentes ac nationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:11:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 11, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per omnes gentes nationesque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:3:87" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 3, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eruditissima Graecorum natio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:4:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 4, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Judaei et Syri, nationes natae servituti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Prov. Cons. 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immanes ac barbarae nationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:9:section=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 9, § 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod eas quoque nationes adire volebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Suevi majorem Germaniae partem obtinent, propriis adhuc nationibus nominibusque discreti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gannascus, natione Canninefas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 11, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">patre Camissare, natione Care, matre Scythissā natus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">NATIONE CILIX,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> p. 495</bibl></cit>, n. 189; so in connection with names of cities: NATIONE ARRETIO, Inscr. Don. cl. 6, n. 181.—</sense><sense id="n30462.4" n="2" level="3"> Ad Nationes, <hi rend="ital">the name of a portico in Rome, built by Augustus</hi>, where the images of all known nations were set up: <cit><quote lang="la">ante aditum porticūs Ad Nationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 39</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 8, 721</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30462.5" n="3" level="3"> In eccl. Lat., like gens, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/qnos</foreign>, opp. to Christians, <hi rend="ital">the heathen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">per deos nationum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Idol. 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
natis: <entryFree id="n30463" type="main" key="na^tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, more freq. in the <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">nă-tes</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>akin to Gr. <foreign lang="greek">nw=ton</foreign>, back; cf. <foreign lang="greek">no/sfi</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n30463.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the rump, the buttocks</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30463.1" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">diffissā nate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Priap.</author> 77, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">83, 23</bibl>: quod ejus natis fulmine icta erat, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. pullus, p. 244 and 245 Müll.—</sense><sense id="n30463.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nates pervellit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 5, 2, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">soleā pulsare nates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:611" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 611</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:18:2" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 18, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">with clunes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:53:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 53, 3</bibl></cit>.—Of <hi rend="ital">the rump</hi> of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">nates turturum donare alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:82:21" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 82, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
natiso: <entryFree id="n30464" type="main" key="Natiso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Natiso</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nati/swn</foreign>, <sense id="n30464.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small Italian river near Aquileia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Natisone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:3" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 18, 22, § 126</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natito: <entryFree id="n30465" type="main" key="na^ti^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nătĭto</orth>, <itype>1</itype>, <sense id="n30465.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [no], <hi rend="ital">to swim</hi> (late Lat.), Anon. (Hilar.) in Job, 1, p. 98.</sense></entryFree>
natiuncula: <entryFree id="n30466" type="gloss" key="na_ti^uncu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātĭuncŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>natio</etym>, <sense id="n30466.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small nation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">natio, natiuncula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 79</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nativitas: <entryFree id="n30467" type="main" key="na_ti_vi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātīvĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nativus</etym>, <sense id="n30467.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">birth, nativity</hi> (post-class.; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">ortus): municipem aut nativitas aut adoptio facit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:1:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">janua nativitatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultum nativitatis,</quote> <trans><tr>natural face</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Jacob. 1, 23</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n30467.1" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Spect. 30</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30467.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A generation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque ad quartam nativitatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 27 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
nativitus: <entryFree id="n30468" type="main" key="na_ti_vi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātīvĭtus</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30468.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">from birth, by birth</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 39</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nativus: <entryFree id="n30469" type="main" key="na_ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nascor</etym>, <sense id="n30469.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has arisen from</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by birth; born</hi> (cf. naturalis). </sense><sense id="n30469.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">mundus,</quote> <trans><tr>made, created</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 417</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Anaximandri opinio est, nativos esse deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:10:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 10, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30469.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30469.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Imparted by birth, inborn, innate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut appareret, in eo nativum quendam leporem esse, non ascitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier si nativā sterilitate sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:2:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 2, 9</bibl></cit>: malum, <hi rend="ital">hunger</hi> (opp. delatum), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 5, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sensus (with domesticus),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:9:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 9, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30469.4" n="B" level="2"> Opp. to artificial, <hi rend="ital">that is produced by nature, not artificial, natural, native</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">beluae partim fluitantes, partim nativis testis inhaerentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:39:100" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 39, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbis (Romae) ipsius nativa praesidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:6:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nativae oves,</quote> <trans><tr>whose wool is used in its natural color</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 73, § 191</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">montes nativi salis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 31, 7, 39, § 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">color,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 32, 7, 24, § 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">specus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arcus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coma,</quote> <trans><tr>original, former, genuine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:14:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 14, 56</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30469.5" n="2" level="3"> In partic., in gram.: nativa verba, <hi rend="ital">primitive words, primitives</hi>: simplicia verba partim nativa sunt, partim reperta: nativa ea quae significata sunt sensu; <cit><quote lang="la">reperta, quae ex his facta sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:5:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 5, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:36" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nato: <entryFree id="n30470" type="main" key="na^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">năto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n30470.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq. n.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">a.</hi> [no], <hi rend="ital">to swim, to float</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30470.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui neque in Oceano natare volueris studiosissimus homo natandi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 10, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natant pisces aequore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:7:28" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 7, 28</bibl></cit>: canis, per flumen, carnem dum ferret, natans, Phaedr. <cb n="NATU" /> 1, 4, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">natat uncta carina,</quote> <trans><tr>floats</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:398" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 398</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crura natantia,</quote> <trans><tr>palmated feet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:551" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 551</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">apta natando crura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:376" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 376</bibl></cit>.—Of storm-tossed or shipwrecked persons, <hi rend="ital">to float about, be tossed about</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragus natans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51:163" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 51, 163</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">trop.: et natat exuviis Graecia pressa tuis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 115: <cit><quote lang="la">cum saepe in portu fracta carina natet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:25:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 25, 24</bibl></cit> (3, 20, 24): <cit><quote lang="la">Ithacum lugere natantem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:257" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 257</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nocte natat caecā serus freta,</quote> <trans><tr>swims across</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 260</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquas,</quote> <trans><tr>to swim in</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:196:2" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 196, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tiberinum,</quote> <trans><tr>to swim across</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:265" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 265</bibl></cit>.—Hence, also, <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quot piscibus unda natatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:2:25" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 2, 25</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n30470.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30470.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To swim</hi> or <hi rend="ital">spread about</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">quā Tiberinus campo liberiore natat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:291" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 291</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natantibus radicibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:Arb. 6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> Arb. 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:12:52" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 12, 52</bibl> (3, 7, 52): <cit><quote lang="la">ingens medio natat umbra profundo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:42" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">niveo natat ignis in ore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Achill. 1, 161</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To swim</hi> or <hi rend="ital">overflow with</hi> any thing, <hi rend="ital">to be overflowed</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>). </sense><sense id="n30470.6" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">natabant pavimenta vino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 41, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plenis Rura natant fossis,</quote> <trans><tr>are inundated</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:372" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 372</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanieque aspersa natarent Limina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:625" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 625</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fletibus ora natant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:337" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 337</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carmina in ipse ore natant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:1:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 1, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.7" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">exspectant imbres, quorum modo cuncta natabant Impulsu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 330</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plana natant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:751" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 751</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.8" n="3" level="3"> Of the eyes, <hi rend="ital">to swim</hi> (of drunken or dying persons), <hi rend="ital">to be feeble, failing</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">vinis oculique animique natabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:673" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 673</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moriens oculis natantibus Circumspexit Athin,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 5, 72</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:122" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 122</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ante oculos natant tenebrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 136</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculi natantes et quādam voluptate suffusi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:3:76" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 3, 76</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.9" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To move to and fro, not stand still</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec vagus in laxā pes tibi pelle (i. e. calceo) natet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:516" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 516</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0830,001:6:43" default="NO"><author>Calp.</author> Ecl. 6, 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Nemes.</author> Cyn. 170</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.10" n="5" level="3"> Of birds, <hi rend="ital">to fly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardea sublimis pennae confisa natanti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:554" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 554</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30470.11" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to fluctuate, waver, be uncertain</hi> ( = titubare, huc atque illuc ferri): <cit><quote lang="la">in quo quidem magis tu mihi natare visus es quam ipse Neptunus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:24:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 24, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mutatio voluntatis indicat animum natare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 35:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 35, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pars multa (hominum) natat, modo recta capessens, Interdum pravis obnoxia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:726" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 726</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 4, 256</bibl>: vitreoque natant praetoria ponto, <hi rend="ital">float</hi> or <hi rend="ital">waver reflected in the water</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:49" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 49</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">nătans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., swimming;</hi> hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">nătantes</orth>, <itype>ūm</itype>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">fishes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus omne natantum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:541" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 541</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:2:section=31" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 3, 2, § 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natrix: <entryFree id="n30471" type="main" key="na_^trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nā^trix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype> (once <gen>m.</gen>: <sense id="n30471.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">natrix violator aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 720</bibl></cit>; usually), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>no</etym>. </sense><sense id="n30471.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A water-snake</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur deus tantam vim natricum viperarumque fecerit?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 38, 120</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30471.2" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of a dangerous person: <cit><quote lang="la">se natricem educare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30471.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a whip, scourge</hi>, made of a watersnake's skin: natibu' natricem impressit crassam et capitatam, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 65, 30</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30471.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A plant</hi>: Ononis natrix, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 12, 83, § 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natta: <entryFree id="n30472" type="main" key="natta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">natta</orth>, v. nacca.</entryFree>
natu: <entryFree id="n30473" type="main" key="na_tu"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātu</orth>, v. 2. natus.</entryFree>
natula: <entryFree id="n30474" type="gloss" key="na_tu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>nata</etym>, <sense id="n30474.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little daughter</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Gud.</author> 335, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
natura: <entryFree id="n30475" type="main" key="na_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nascor</etym>, <sense id="n30475.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">birth.</hi> </sense><sense id="n30475.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">naturā tu illi pater es, consiliis ego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 46</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">naturā pater,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 7, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> (freq. and class.; syn.: indoles, ingenium). </sense><sense id="n30475.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The nature</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the natural constitution, property</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">quality</hi> of a thing: <cit><quote lang="la">quod autem animal est, id motu cietur interiore et suo: nam haec est natura propria animae et vis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:26:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 26, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsumque per se sua vi, sua natura, sua sponte laudabile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:15:50" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 15, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab ipsa natura loci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:35:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 35, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quali esset natura montis, qui cognoscerent misit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loci,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: tigna secundum naturam fluminis procumberent, <hi rend="ital">according to the nature</hi> or <hi rend="ital">natural course of the river</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 17</bibl>: insula naturā triquetra, <hi rend="ital">by nature</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">in shape</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturas apibus quas Juppiter ipse Addidit expediam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 149</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.4" n="2" level="3"> Of character, <hi rend="ital">nature, natural disposition, inclination, bent, temper, character</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cognitum per te ipsum, quae tua natura est, dignum tuā amicitiā judicabis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:78:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 78, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prolixa beneficaque,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 8, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 59</bibl>: mihi benefacere jam ex consuetudine <pb n="1190" /> <cb n="NATU" /> in naturam vertit, <hi rend="ital">has become natural</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 85, 9</bibl>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">consuetudo est secunda natura,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>August.</author> adv. Jul. 5, 59 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 7, 9, 7</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">voluptatem consuetudine quasi alteram naturam effici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:25:74" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 25, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturam expellas furcā, tamen usque recurret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere sibi naturam alicujus rei,</quote> <trans><tr>to accustom one's self to a thing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:4:17" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">desideria naturae satiare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:8:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 8, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The nature, course</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">order</hi> of things: <cit><quote lang="la">quod rerum natura non patitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 17, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">delabi ad aequitatem et ad rerum naturam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:10:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 10, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturae satisfacere,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to die</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 10, 29</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">naturae concedere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 15</bibl></cit>:—Personified: <cit><quote lang="la">quis vero opifex praeter naturam, quā nihil potest esse callidius, tantam sollertiam persequi potuisset in sensibus? quae primum oculos membranis tenuissimis vestivit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:57:142" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 57, 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frui primis a natura datis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:11:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 11, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines rationem habent a naturā datam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 14, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et homini praecipui a naturā nihil datum esse dicemus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 33, 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (membra corporum) ipsa declarant procreandi a naturā habitam esse rationem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 19, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis natura vult esse conservatrix sui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 7, 16</bibl></cit>; 5, 15, 41; <cit><quote lang="la">5, 20, 56: illam partem bene vivendi a natura petebant, eique parendum esse dicebant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 5, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Nature</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the world, the universe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cleanthes totius naturae menti atque animo hoc nomen (dei) tribuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:14:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 14, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.7" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Nature</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">consistency with nature, possibility</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in rerum naturā fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 8, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc quoque in rerum naturam cadit,</quote> <trans><tr>is a possible case</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:17:32" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 17, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicatum est enim, rerum naturam non recipere, ut, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>that it is not in accordance with nature, not possible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 1</bibl></cit>, abs. 13:—</sense><sense id="n30475.8" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An element, thing, substance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aristoteles quin tam quandam naturam censet esse, e qua sit mens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:10:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 10, 22</bibl></cit>: de naturis autem sic sentiebat; <cit><quote lang="la">primum uti quattuor initiis rerum illis quintam hanc naturam ... non adhiberet, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 11, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natura tenuis aëris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:232" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 232</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30475.9" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The natural parts, organs of generation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (Mercurii) obscenius excitata natura traditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:22:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 22, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam matrona visa est in quiete obsignatam habere naturam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:70:145" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 70, 145</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:12:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 12, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:2:7:8" default="NO">2, 7, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naturabilis: <entryFree id="n30476" type="main" key="na_tu_ra_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, i. q. naturalis, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Doct. Plat. 2, p. 19, 6</bibl>.</entryFree>
naturalis: <entryFree id="n30477" type="main" key="na_tu_ra_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>natura</etym>, <sense id="n30477.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">natural</hi>, i. e., </sense><sense id="n30477.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">By birth, one's own</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturalis pater, opp. to adoptive father,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 6, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adoptionem dato redire in familiam liceat, si pater naturalis sine liberis decesserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:96" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 96</bibl></cit>: filius ( = <foreign lang="greek">kata\ fu/sin ui/o/s</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pauli nepos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 44, 44</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:52" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:Inst. 2:137" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> Inst. 2, 137</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:3:31" default="NO">3, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in avi sui naturalis potestate est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:8:1:section=2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 37, 8, 1, § 2</bibl></cit>; also, <hi rend="ital">natural, illegitimate</hi> ( = nothus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:5:40" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 5, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:36:1:80:section=2" default="NO">36, 1, 80, § 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 6:12" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 6, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 945, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30477.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the nature of things, produced by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">agreeable to nature, natural</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturale est alicui,</quote> <trans><tr>it is natural to one, it is his innate quality</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37</bibl></cit>. 54, § <cit><quote lang="la">144: historia, id. praef. § 1: motus naturalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">societas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:16:50" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 16, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:14:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 14, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">notio naturalis atque insita in animis nostris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:9:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 9, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturalis, non fucatus nitor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:9:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 9, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bonum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 5, 11</bibl></cit>: dies, <hi rend="ital">a natural day</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">from sunrise to sunset</hi>, opp. to the dies civilis, <bibl default="NO"><author>Censor.</author> de Die Nat. 23</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. civilis: mors,</quote> <trans><tr>a natural, not a violent death</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 53, 54, § 180</bibl></cit> (for the class. mors necessaria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 7, 16</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">naturales exitus,</quote> <trans><tr>the anus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:30:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 30, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturalia desideria,</quote> <trans><tr>the serual impulse</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:24:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 24, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:27:7" default="NO">6, 27, 7</bibl>: loca naturalia, <hi rend="ital">the sexual parts</hi> of men and animals, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1, p. 11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, p. 11</bibl> Milligan.—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the private parts</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanguinis pars per naturale descendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 26, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:26:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 26, 1 al.</bibl>—More freq. <number>plur.</number>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, in same sense, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 21 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:20:4" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 20, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:18:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 18, 2 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:27:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 27, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:4:2" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 4, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30477.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">concerning nature, natural</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturales quaestiones,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. 18, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">historia, Plin. H. N. praef. § 1: philosophia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 2, 24, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30477.4" n="IV" level="1"> Opp. to fictitious, <hi rend="ital">natural, real</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">philosophi duos Joves fecerunt, unum naturalem, alterum fabulosum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 11</bibl></cit>. —Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">naturally</hi>, <cb n="NAUC" /> <hi rend="ital">conformably to nature, by nature</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec vero umquam animus hominis naturaliter divinat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:50:113" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 50, 113</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacritas naturaliter innata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter naturaliter dissimillimos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:60:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 60, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 47, § 130</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">profluere (urinam),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:26:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 26, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. Alex. 8" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. Alex. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">est aliquid in omni materiā naturaliter primum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:8:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 8, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naturalitas: <entryFree id="n30478" type="main" key="na_tu_ra_li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>naturalis</etym>, <sense id="n30478.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">naturainess</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">somni naturalitas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naturaliter: <entryFree id="n30479" type="main" key="na_tu_ra_li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. naturalis <sense id="n30479.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
naturalitus: <entryFree id="n30480" type="main" key="na_tu_ra_li^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrālĭtus</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>naturalis</etym>, <sense id="n30480.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">by nature</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 9, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1, 12, p. 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naturificatus: <entryFree id="n30481" type="main" key="na_tu_ri^fi^ca_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātūrĭfĭcātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naturafacio</etym>, <sense id="n30481.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">brought into being</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">animae naturificatae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Valent. 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
natus: <entryFree id="n30482" type="main" key="na_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <sense id="n30482.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a., born. —Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nātus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a son;</hi> v. nascor <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30483" type="main" key="na_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype> (used only in <sense id="n30483.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi>), <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nascor</etym>, lit. <hi rend="ital">birth;</hi> hence, * </sense><sense id="n30483.1" n="I" level="1"> Of plants, <hi rend="ital">a growing, growth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupressus natu morosa,</quote> <trans><tr>slow of growth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 33, 60, § 139</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n30483.2" n="II" level="1"> With esp. reference to age, <hi rend="ital">birth, age, years</hi> (the class. signif. of the word): <cit><quote lang="la">non admodum grandis natu,</quote> <trans><tr>not very old</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:4:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantus natu,</quote> <trans><tr>so old</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">grandior natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">P. Scaptius de plebe magno natu,</quote> <trans><tr>an old man</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:71:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 71, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo magno natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:38:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 38, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magno natu principes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:34:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 34, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicitur matrem Pausaniae vixisse eamque jam magno natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 5, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dat. 7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Tim. 3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tim. 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui fuit major natu, quam Plautus,</quote> <trans><tr>older</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ille Q. Scaevolam sibi minorem natu generum praetulisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:26:101" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 26, 101</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est tibi frater pari nobilitate, natu major,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">audivi ex majoribus natu hoc idem fuisse in P. Scipione Nasicā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:30:109" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 30, 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex iis (filiis) duo natu majores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:10:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minorem natu, quam ipse erat, fratrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:ad Polyb. 15:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> ad Polyb. 15, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frater major natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 13, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id meā minime refert qui sum natu maximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 4, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeter Philippum maximum natu ex filiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 6, 9</bibl></cit>: qui maximus natu esset ex liberis ejus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 1, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita enim maximus ex iis in concilio respondit,</quote> <trans><tr>the oldest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 19 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">filius non maximus natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex his omnibus natu minimus, Q. Saturius est,</quote> <trans><tr>the youngest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:38:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 38, 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maximo natu filius, for maximus natu,</quote> <trans><tr>his eldest son</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 7, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nauarchia: <entryFree id="n30484" type="main" key="nauarchia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauarchia</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nauarxi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n30484.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the command of a vessel</hi>, Cod. Th. 13, 5, 20.</sense></entryFree>
nauarchus: <entryFree id="n30485" type="main" key="nauarchus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauarchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (less correctly <orth extent="full" lang="la">nav-</orth>), = <foreign lang="greek">nau/arxos</foreign>, <sense id="n30485.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the master of a vessel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:24:section=60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 24, § 60</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3615</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3624</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 5, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naubolides: <entryFree id="n30486" type="main" key="Naubo^li^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naubŏlĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. Naubolus, II.</entryFree>
naubolus: <entryFree id="n30487" type="main" key="Naubo^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naubŏlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/bolos</foreign>, <sense id="n30487.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of Phocis, father of Iphitus the Argonaut</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:355" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 355</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 14" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 14</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30487.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naubŏlĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the son of Naubolus</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Iphitus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:362" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 362</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:354" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 354</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauci: <entryFree id="n30488" type="main" key="nauci"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauci</orth>, v. naucum.</entryFree>
nauclericus: <entryFree id="n30489" type="greek" key="naucle_ri^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauclērĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">nauklhriko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n30489.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a ship-owner</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ship-master</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facito uti venias (ornatu) ornatus huc nauclerico,</quote> <trans><tr>in a skipper's dress</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 4, 41</bibl></cit> (MSS. nauclerioco): <cit><quote lang="la">nauclerico ornatu,</quote> <trans><tr>in the dress of a ship-master</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 1, 1, 54</bibl></cit> (MSS. nauclerio), for which ornatus thalassicus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:6:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 6, 67</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauclerius: <entryFree id="n30490" type="greek" key="naucle_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauclērĭus</orth>, v. l. for nauclericus, q. v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 1, 54</bibl>.</entryFree>
nauclerus: <entryFree id="n30491" type="greek" key="naucle_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauclērus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nau/klhros</foreign>, <sense id="n30491.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shipowner, a ship-master, skipper</hi> (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">navarchus, gubernator),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 3, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:27:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 27, 11</bibl>; Cod. Th. 7, 16, 3; Firm. Math. 8, 20 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n30491.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nauclērus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the title of a comedy of Cæcilius</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 12, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">126, 26</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">506, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 19, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naucrates: <entryFree id="n30492" type="main" key="Naucra^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naucrătes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*naukra/ths</foreign>, <sense id="n30492.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek historian of Erythræ, a pupil of Isocrates</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:23:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 23, 94</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 44, 173</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:51:172" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 51, 172</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:6:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 6, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naucratis: <entryFree id="n30493" type="main" key="Naucra^tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naucrătis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/kratis</foreign>, <sense id="n30493.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of the Delta in Egypt</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Salhadschar</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 10, 11, § 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:111" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 10, 46, § 111</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n30493.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naucrătītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <hi rend="ital">adj., of Naucratis, Naucratian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 9, § 49</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30493.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naucrătĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <cb n="NAUF" /> <hi rend="ital">Naucratian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ostium Nili,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 10, 11, § 64</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naucula: <entryFree id="n30494" type="main" key="naucu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naucŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>navicula</etym>, <sense id="n30494.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little ship</hi>, for navicula (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:6:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 6, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Carm. 21, 247</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">naucula, navicella, navicula,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 177</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nauculor: <entryFree id="n30495" type="main" key="naucu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naucŭlor</orth>, v. naviculor.</entryFree>
naucum: <entryFree id="n30496" type="main" key="naucum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naucum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">naucus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>etym. dub.; cf. hugae</etym>, <sense id="n30496.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">something slight</hi> or <hi rend="ital">trivial, a trifle</hi>: naucum ait Ateius Philologus poni pro nugis. Cincius, quod in oleae nucis, quod intus sit. Aelius Stilo omnium rerum putamen. Glossematorum autem scriptores fabae grani quod haereat in fabulo. Quidam ex Graeco quod sit <foreign lang="greek">vai\ kai\ ou)xi/</foreign>, levem hominem significari. Quidam nucis juglandis, quam Verrius jugulandam vocat, medium velut dissaepimentum. Plautus in Parasito pigro: Ambo magnā laude lauti, postremo ambo sumus non nauci.
