Item in Mostellaria: Quod id esse dicam verbum nauci, nescio; et in Truculento: Amas hominem non nauci; et Naevius in Tunicularia: Ejus noctem nauco ducere (<hi rend="ital">to value at nothing</hi>); et Ennius: Illuc nugator nili, non nauci'st homo, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=166" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 166</bibl> Müll. (<bibl default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Com. v. 10</bibl> Vahl.).—Besides the preceding example from Naevius, non nauci (habere, facere, or esse, used only in the genitive with a negative), <hi rend="ital">of no value, good for nothing</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">flocci habeo): non habeo denique nauci Marsum augurem,</quote> <trans><tr>esteem lightly, value not a straw</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:58:132" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 58, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo timidus nauci non erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 5, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo non nauci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc servum meum non nauci facere esse ausum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naufragabilis: <entryFree id="n30497" type="main" key="naufra^ga_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naufragium</etym>, <sense id="n30497.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dangerous to ships</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> Ep. 2, p. 1134</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naufragalis: <entryFree id="n30498" type="main" key="naufra^ga_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30498.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">where many shipwrecks occur, dangerous to ships</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capraria naufragalis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, § 643</bibl></cit>; cf. naufragiosus.</sense></entryFree>
naufragator: <entryFree id="n30499" type="main" key="naufra^ga_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>naufrago</etym>, <sense id="n30499.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shipwrecked person</hi> (late Lat.), Aug. Serm. in Spicil. Rom. t. 8.</sense></entryFree>
naufragiosus: <entryFree id="n30500" type="main" key="naufra^gi^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naufragium</etym>, <sense id="n30500.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of shipwrecks, dangerous to ships</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pelagus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud. Mam.</author> de Stat. Anim. 1, 1</bibl>; cf. naufragalis.</sense></entryFree>
naufragium: <entryFree id="n30501" type="main" key="naufra^gi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>for navifragium, from navis-frango</etym>, <sense id="n30501.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shipwreck</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30501.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">multi naufragia fecerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragio perire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:9:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 9, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragio interire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragio interceptus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:10:7" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 10, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullum conferri posse Naufragium velis ardentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:22" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 12, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 118" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 118</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragia alicujus ex terrā intueri,</quote> <trans><tr>to behold the ruin of others from a position of safety</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 7, 4</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">naufragium in portu facere,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to fail when on the verge of success</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 12:23" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 12, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30501.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, transf. </sense><sense id="n30501.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A storm</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragiis magnis multisque coörtis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:552" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 552</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30501.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The remains of a shipwreck, a wreck</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Eurus Naufragium spargens operit freta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:323" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 323</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30501.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">shipwreck, ruin, loss, destruction</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragium fortunarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:9:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 9, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luculenti patrimonii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 12, 8, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rei familiaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Gallica gens per Italiam naufragia sua latius traheret,</quote> <trans><tr>defeats</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:13:19" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 13, 19</bibl></cit>: tabula ex naufragio, lit. <hi rend="ital">a plank on which a shipwrecked person saves himself;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">a means of deliverance, a solace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 18, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30501.6" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the shattered remains, a wreck</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragia Caesaris amicorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: colligere naufragium rei publicae. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 6, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">credo mollia naufragiis litora posse dari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:2:62" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 2, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 9, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naufrago: <entryFree id="n30502" type="main" key="naufra^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgo</orth>, <itype>āvi, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>naufragus</etym>, <sense id="n30502.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to suffer shipwreck, be wrecked</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes naves naufragārunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 76, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 21</bibl>; Salv. Gub. Dei, 3, p. 77.</sense></entryFree>
naufragus: <entryFree id="n30503" type="main" key="naufra^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navis-frango</etym>, <sense id="n30503.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that suffers shipwreck, shipwrecked, wrecked</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30503.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">Marium Africa devicta expulsum et naufragum vidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:19:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 19, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:542" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 542</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">puppis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30503.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">naufrăgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a shipwrecked person</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragus natans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51:153" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 51, 153</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare naufrago tabulam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 3:9:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 3, 9, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mersā rate naufragus assem Dum rogat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14</bibl></cit>. <pb n="1191" /> <cb n="NAUS" /> 301.—</sense><sense id="n30503.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, transf., <hi rend="ital">that causes shipwreck, shipwrecking</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:16:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 16, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:4:10" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">monstra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:500" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 500</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:584" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 584</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syrtis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:635" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 17, 635</bibl></cit>; cf. navifragus.—</sense><sense id="n30503.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">ruined</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naufragorum ejecta ac debilitata manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:11:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 11, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut aliquis patrimonio naufragus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:14:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 14, 41</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naulia: <entryFree id="n30504" type="greek" key="nauli^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naulĭa</orth>, v. nablium.</entryFree>
naulocha: <entryFree id="n30505" type="main" key="Naulo^cha"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naulŏcha</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">Naulŏchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:116" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 116</bibl>), <sense id="n30505.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a village on the north coast of Sicily, near the promontory of Pelorus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:265" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 265</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naulum: <entryFree id="n30506" type="greek" key="naulum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naulum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">naulŏn</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nau=lon</foreign>, <sense id="n30506.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">passage-money, fare</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">perdere naulon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:97" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in naulis navium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30:39:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 30, 39, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut naulum exsolvatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:20:4:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 20, 4, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Jonae, 1, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naumachia: <entryFree id="n30507" type="greek" key="nauma^chi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naumăchĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">naumaxi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n30507.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the representation of a sea-fight, a mock seafight</hi> (pure Lat. navale proelium). </sense><sense id="n30507.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">naumachiam commisit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naumachiae spectaculum edere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naumachiam exhibere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:56:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 56, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:100:2" default="NO">2, 100, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Spect. 28:12" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Spect. 28, 12</bibl>: voluptates naumachiae, Vopisc. Aur. 34, 6. —</sense><sense id="n30507.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a place where mock seafights were exhibited</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">edidit et navale proelium in veteri naumachia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">72</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naumachiarius: <entryFree id="n30508" type="main" key="nauma^chi^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naumăchĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>naumachia</etym>, <sense id="n30508.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">for a mock sea-fight</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:190" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 39, 74, § 190</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30508.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nau-măchĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a combatant in a mock sea-fight</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naumachus: <entryFree id="n30509" type="gloss" key="nauma^chus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naumăchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nau/maxos</foreign>, <sense id="n30509.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a naval combatant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nauta, nauticus, naumachus, naumachia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Not. Tir.</author> p. 77</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naupactous: <entryFree id="n30510" type="main" key="Naupacto_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naupactōus</orth>, v. Naupactus, II.</entryFree>
naupactus: <entryFree id="n30511" type="main" key="Naupactus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naupactus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-os</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nau-pactum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/paktos</foreign>, <sense id="n30511.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Ætolia, on the Gulf of Corinth</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Epakto</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Lepanto</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:37:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 37, 91</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34" default="NO" valid="yes">34</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 2, 3, § 6</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30511.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naupactōus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Naupactian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Naupactous Achelous,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:43" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 43</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naupegiarius: <entryFree id="n30512" type="gloss" key="naupe_gi^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naupēgĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>naupegus</etym>, <sense id="n30512.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a ship-carpenter</hi>, Inscr. Spon. Miscell. p. 67.</sense></entryFree>
naupegus: <entryFree id="n30513" type="greek" key="naupe_gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naupēgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nauphgo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n30513.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shipbuilder, shipwright, ship-carpenter</hi>: naupego in navi maritimā diurni X sexaginta, Edict. Diocl. p. 19; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:6:6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 6, 6</bibl>; Firm. Math. 4, 7 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nauphylax: <entryFree id="n30514" type="gloss" key="nauphy^lax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauphylax</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">naufylax, naufŭ-lax</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">năŏfylax</orth>), <itype>ăcis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">naufu/lac</foreign>, <sense id="n30514.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who kept watch over the luggage on shipboard</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Don.</author> 273, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Maff.</author> Mus. Ver. 125, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naupidame: <entryFree id="n30515" type="main" key="Naupi^da^me_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naupĭdămē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*naupida/mh</foreign>, <sense id="n30515.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">daughter of Amphidamas, and mother of Augeas by Helios</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 14" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauplius: <entryFree id="n30516" type="main" key="Naupli^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nauplĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/plios</foreign>, <sense id="n30516.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Neptune and Amymone, king of Eubœa, and father of Palamedes. To avenge his son, whom the Greeks had put to death before Troy, he made false signal-fires on the shores of Eubœa as the Greeks were returning homeward, and led them to shipwreck upon the rocks</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nauplius ultores sub noctem porrigit ignes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 115; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. A. 11, 260</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 116" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 116</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nauplii mala,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 39</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30516.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nauplĭădes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nauplia/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the son of Nauplius</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Palamedes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 39</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">310</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:621" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ib. 621</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30517" type="greek" key="naupli^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauplĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nau/plios</foreign>, <sense id="n30517.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of shell-fish, which sails in its shell as in a ship</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 30, 49, § 94</bibl>; v. naviger.</sense></entryFree>
nauportum: <entryFree id="n30518" type="main" key="Nauportum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nauportum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n30518.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Upper Pannonia</hi>, the mod. <hi rend="ital">Laybach</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:110:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 110, 4</bibl>.—Near it is the river <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nau-portus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 18, 22, § 128</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naura: <entryFree id="n30519" type="main" key="Naura"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naura</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. Nautaca.</entryFree>
nauscit: <entryFree id="n30520" type="gloss" key="nauscit"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauscit</orth> (qs. naviscit), said of a bean, which opens in the shape of a ship, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=168" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 168</bibl> and 169 Müll.</entryFree>
nausea: <entryFree id="n30521" type="greek" key="nause^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nausi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n30521.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sea-sickness</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30521.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne nauseae molestiam suscipias aeger,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 11, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigavimus sine timore et nauseā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 13, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nauseā pressus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30521.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">sickness, nausea; vomiting</hi> (syn. fastidium): <cit><quote lang="la">nausea segnis, quae bilem movet nec effundit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 53:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 53, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cruditates, quae nauseam faciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 11, 69, § 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">elaeomeli non sine nauseā alvum solvit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 4, 50, § 96</bibl></cit>: nauseam fluentem coërcere. <cb n="NAUT" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:9:35" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 9, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi libido veniet nauseae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 156</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30521.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a qualm, nausea</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cotidianam refice nauseam nummis. Audire gratis, Afer, ista non possum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:37:9" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 37, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseabilis: <entryFree id="n30522" type="main" key="nause^a_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nauseo</etym>, <sense id="n30522.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that causes nausea</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vomiting</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:2:18" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 3, 2, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseabundus: <entryFree id="n30523" type="main" key="nause^a_bundus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕābundus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30523.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inclined to vomit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 108:35" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 108, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:47:6" default="NO">47, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseator: <entryFree id="n30524" type="main" key="nause^a_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30524.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who is apt to feel nausea, who vomits easily</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ulixes nauseator erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 53:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 53, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseo: <entryFree id="n30525" type="main" key="nause^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>nausea</etym>, <sense id="n30525.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be sea-sick</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30525.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 93</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si sine vomitu nauseavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30525.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to be squeamish</hi> or <hi rend="ital">qualmish, to vomit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quidlibet, modo ne nauseet, faciat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:34:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 34, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ructantem et nauseantem Antonium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:25:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 12, 25, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:433" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 433</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30525.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30525.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To belch forth</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">give vent to, utter</hi> nonsense: <cit><quote lang="la">ista effutientem nauseare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:30:84" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 30, 84</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30525.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To cause disgust</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc illis dictum est, qui stultitiā nauseant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:4:7:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 4, 7, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseola: <entryFree id="n30526" type="hapax" key="nause^o^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30526.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a slight squeamishness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 14, 8, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauseosus: <entryFree id="n30527" type="hapax" key="nause^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausĕōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30527.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that produces nausea, nauseous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">radix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 8, 38, § 59</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nausicaa: <entryFree id="n30528" type="main" key="Nausi^ca^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nausĭcăa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nausĭcăē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nausika/a</foreign>, <sense id="n30528.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the daughter of Atcinoüs, king of the Phæacians</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgo Nausicaa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:9:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 9, 14</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Per. Odyss. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 125 sq" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 125 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nausicaë patrii horti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:31:9" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 31, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nausiphanes: <entryFree id="n30529" type="main" key="Nausi^pha^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nausĭphănes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nausifa/nhs</foreign>, <sense id="n30529.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Grecian philosopher of Teos, instructor of Epicurus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:26:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 26, 33</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nausiphous: <entryFree id="n30530" type="main" key="Nausi^pho^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nausĭphŏus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30530.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the son of Ulysses by Circe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 125" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 125</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nausistrata: <entryFree id="n30531" type="main" key="Nausistra^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nausistrăta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30531.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:7:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 7, 94</bibl> et passim.</sense></entryFree>
naustathmos: <entryFree id="n30532" type="main" key="Naustathmos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naustathmos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/staqmos</foreign>, <sense id="n30532.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a seaport in Ionia, near Phocæa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 31 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
naustibulum: <entryFree id="n30533" type="gloss" key="nausti^bu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naustĭbŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>navis</etym>, <sense id="n30533.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a vessel shaped like a ship</hi>: naustibulum vocabant antiqui vas alvei simile, videlicet a navis similitudine, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=168" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 168</bibl> and 169 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
nausum: <entryFree id="n30534" type="foreign" key="nausum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nausum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n30534.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of Gallic ship</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nauso advehi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> <hi rend="ital">in carm</hi>.</sense></entryFree>
nauta: <entryFree id="n30535" type="main" key="nauta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nauta</orth> (ante-class., <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, and late Lat. <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭta</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>for navita, from navis</etym>, <sense id="n30535.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sailor, seaman, mariner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego nautas eum non putabam habiturum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 9, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">nautas gubernatoresque comparari jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pavidus nauta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nautae = mercatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">permixtus nautis et furibus et fugitivis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:174" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 174</bibl></cit>.—Uncontracted form navita (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">nulla est voluptas navitis major,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; Cato ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">timidi navitae, Cic. poët. Tusc. 2, 10, 23: navita de ventis, de tauris narrat arator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:1:43" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navita tum stellis numeros et nomina fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 137</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis navita ponto Umida vela legit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 372</bibl></cit> sq.: <cit><quote lang="la">navitas precum ejus (Arionis) commiseritum esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:19:11" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 19, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. Charon. Ap. M. 6, 20, p. 181; so, <cit><quote lang="la">navita turpis aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:10:36" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 10, 36</bibl></cit>: navita Porthmeus, Petr. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> 121, 117.</sense></entryFree>
nautaca: <entryFree id="n30536" type="main" key="Nauta^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nautăca</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nau/taka</foreign>, <sense id="n30536.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Sogdiana, near the river Oxus, probably between the mod. Samarcand and the river Amur</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:2:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 2, 9</bibl> (ex conject., Zumpt and Mütz. for Naura).</sense></entryFree>
nautalis: <entryFree id="n30537" type="main" key="nauta_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nautālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nauta</etym>, <sense id="n30537.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sailor-like</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">forma,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 10, 223</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nautea: <entryFree id="n30538" type="greek" key="naute^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nauti/a</foreign> (another form for <foreign lang="greek">nausi/a</foreign>). *<sense id="n30538.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A qualm, nausea</hi>: nauteam facere, Plaut. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=165" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 165</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n30538.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An offensive liquid</hi>, perh. <hi rend="ital">bilgewater</hi> = sentina: <cit><quote lang="la">nautea est aqua de coriis, vel, quod est verius, aqua de sentinā, dicta a nautis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 8, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nauteam Bibere malim, si necessum est, quam illanc oscularier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 5, 2, 44</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 5</bibl>: hircus unctus nauteā, id. Cas. grex. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—(Acc. to Opilius Aurelius ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=165" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 165</bibl> Müll., nautea is <hi rend="ital">a plant used by tanners</hi>: nauteam ait Opilius Aurelius herbam esse granis nigris, quā coriarii utuntur, a nave ductum nomen, quia nauseam facit, permutatione T et S; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=164" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> p. 164</bibl> ib.) <cb n="NAVA" /></sense></entryFree>
nautes: <entryFree id="n30539" type="main" key="Nautes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nautes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30539.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the primogenitor of the</hi> Nautii (v. h. v.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:704" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 704</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">728</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nauticarius: <entryFree id="n30540" type="gloss" key="nauti^ca_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĭcārĭus</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nauta</etym>, <sense id="n30540.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shipmaster</hi>, Inscr. Fea Fast. Cons. 40.</sense></entryFree>
nauticus: <entryFree id="n30541" type="greek" key="nauti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">nautiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n30541.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to ships</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sailors, ship-, nautical</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inhibere est verbum totum nauticum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exuviae nauticae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:18:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 18, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scientia nauticarum rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 8</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 60</bibl> 152: <cit><quote lang="la">clamor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 128</bibl></cit>. panis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 68, § 138</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecunia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:45:1:122" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 45, 1, 122</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30541.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĭci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">sailors, seamen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Macrin nautici vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:3" default="NO" valid="yes">41, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 37, 70, § 178</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nautii: <entryFree id="n30542" type="main" key="Nauti^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nautĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30542.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Nautians, a Roman family, descended from Nautes the Trojan, who brought the image of Minerva to Italy. The sacrifices to Minerva remained in this family, and the goddess herself was called</hi> Dea Nautia, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 2, 166</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 407</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 704</bibl> and 728; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=166" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 166</bibl> and 167 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
nautilus: <entryFree id="n30543" type="greek" key="nauti^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĭlus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">nautĭlŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nauti/los</foreign>, <sense id="n30543.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the nautilus, a shell-fish so called because it sails like a vessel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 29, 47, § 88</bibl>; cf. nauplius and naviger.</sense></entryFree>
nautius: <entryFree id="n30544" type="main" key="Nauti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nautĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n30544.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens. </sense><sense id="n30544.1" n="1" level="3"> C. Nautius, <hi rend="ital">a consul</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 25</bibl> sq.— </sense><sense id="n30544.2" n="2" level="3"> C. Nautius Rutilus, <hi rend="ital">a consul</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 52</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n30544.3" n="3" level="3"> Sp. Nautius Rutilus, <hi rend="ital">a military tribune</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 35</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nava: <entryFree id="n30545" type="main" key="Na_va"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāva</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30545.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Germany which flows into the Rhine near Bingen</hi>, now the <hi rend="ital">Nahe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 70</bibl>; Aus Mosell. 1.</sense></entryFree>
navaculum: <entryFree id="n30546" type="gloss" key="na_va_cu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvācŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>navis</etym>, <sense id="n30546.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a harbor</hi>: navaculum, <foreign lang="greek">nau/staqmon</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
navale: <entryFree id="n30547" type="main" key="na_va_le"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvāle</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, v. navalis, II.</entryFree>
navalis: <entryFree id="n30548" type="main" key="na_va_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navis</etym>, <sense id="n30548.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to ships, ship-, naval</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestres navalesve pugnae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:5:13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 5, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:51:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 51, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Imp. Pomp. 10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 10, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apparatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Att. 10:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 8, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disciplina et gloria navalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Imp. Pomp. 18:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 18, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fuga,</quote> <trans><tr>by sea</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 45, 46, § 148</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proelium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:6:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra,</quote> <trans><tr>to protect the ships drawn up on land</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in classe acieque navali esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:51:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 51, 8</bibl></cit> Weissenb.: <cit><quote lang="la">forma,</quote> <trans><tr>the shape of a ship</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:229" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 229</bibl></cit>: corona, <hi rend="ital">a naval crown</hi>, as the reward of a naval victory, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:684" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 684</bibl>; cf.: navali coronā solet donari, qui primus in hostium navem armatus transilierit, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=163" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 163</bibl> Müll.; so, <cit><quote lang="la">navali cinctus honore caput,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:392" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 392</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navali surgentes aere columnae,</quote> <trans><tr>made of the brass from the beaks of captured ships</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arbor,</quote> <trans><tr>fit for ship-building</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 9, 17, § 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stagnum,</quote> <trans><tr>a basin in which to exhibit mock sea-fights</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navalis Phoebus, so called because hegranted the victory at Actium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 3; v. Actius and Actiacus: socii, <hi rend="ital">sailors, seamen</hi> (chosen from the freedmen of the colonists and allies, and also from those of the colonists and allies themselves who had been in slavery; they were bound to a longer period of service and were of lower rank than the land troops; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:18" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:50" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 50</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">postero die militibus navalibusque sociis convocatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:17" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:23" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 23</bibl>; 26, 35; <cit><quote lang="la">24, 11.—Sometimes the socii navales are distinguished from the seamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navales pedes, contemptuously,</quote> <trans><tr>galley-slaves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:2:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 2, 75</bibl></cit>. (Others understand by this expression <hi rend="ital">ship-servants, cabin-boys</hi>. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 381, 393</bibl>, calls the <hi rend="ital">oars</hi> themselves navales pedes).— <cit><quote lang="la">Duumviri navales,</quote> <trans><tr>two commissaries who were charged with the repairing and fitting out of a fleet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:18" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26" default="NO" valid="yes">26</bibl>: navalis scriba, <hi rend="ital">a ship's scribe</hi> or <hi rend="ital">secretary</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n30548.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvā-le</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (in <number>sing.</number> only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>), and <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvā-lĭa</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (<hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> navaliorum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 127</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3627</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n30548.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A place where ships were built and repaired, a dock, dockyard</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">statio, portus): navalia, portus, aquarum ductus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:17:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 17, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de navalium opere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:14:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 14, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deripientque rates alii navalibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:593" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 593</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:455" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 455</bibl>.—In <number>sing.</number>, haud aliter quam si siccum navale teneret (puppis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:661" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 661</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:18:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 18, 207</bibl>.—Esp. of <hi rend="ital">the place in Rome, across the Tiber, where the dock-yards were situated</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:14:12" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 14, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:51" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 51</bibl> et saep.—Near them was the Navalis porta, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=178" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 178</bibl> Müll.— </sense><sense id="n30548.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The requisites for fitting out a ship</hi>, <pb n="1192" /> <cb n="NAVI" /> <hi rend="ital">tackling, rigging</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:23:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 23, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:329" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 329</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 11, 21, § 52</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
navanter: <entryFree id="n30549" type="main" key="na_vanter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvanter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. navo <sense id="n30549.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
navarchus: <entryFree id="n30550" type="greek" key="na_varchus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvarchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nau/arxos</foreign>, v. nauarchus.</entryFree>
nave: <entryFree id="n30551" type="main" key="na_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. navus <sense id="n30551.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> * A.</sense></entryFree>
navia: <entryFree id="n30552" type="main" key="na_vi^a" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>navis</etym>. <sense id="n30552.0" n="I" level="1"> A corruption of navis, <hi rend="ital">a ship;</hi> in the proverb, aut caputa aut naviam for aut caput aut navim (v. caput), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Orig. Gent. R. 3" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Orig. Gent. R. 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> 38, 73</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30552.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a bark, boat, canoe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">harundinum fissa internodia, velut navia, binos et quaedam ternos etiam vehant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 7</bibl></cit>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">a trough</hi>: navia lignum cavatum ut navis, quo in vindemiis uti solent, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169:25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169, 25</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
naviaficus: <entryFree id="n30553" type="main" key="Navia ficus" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Navia ficus</orth>, v. Navius.</entryFree>
navicella: <entryFree id="n30554" type="main" key="na_vi^cella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcella</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">naucella</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>navis</etym>, <sense id="n30554.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small vessel, a boat, skiff</hi> (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">navicellae, quae piscium capiendorum causā paratae sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:33:7:17:section=1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 33, 7, 17, § 1</bibl></cit> (al. naucellae).</sense></entryFree>
navicula: <entryFree id="n30555" type="main" key="na_vi^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30555.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small vessel, a boat, skiff</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos ad naviculas nostras descendimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 48, 148</bibl></cit>; Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 238, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 3</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 104</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
navicularia: <entryFree id="n30556" type="main" key="na_vi^cu^la_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlārĭa</orth>, v. navicularius.</entryFree>
navicularis: <entryFree id="n30557" type="main" key="na_vi^cu^la_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navicula</etym>, <sense id="n30557.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to the shipping business</hi> (postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:4:1:section=1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 4, 1, § 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
navicularius: <entryFree id="n30558" type="main" key="na_vi^cu^la_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30558.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a small ship, boat</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">vessel</hi> (late Lat.): onus, Cod. Th. 13, 5, 12: PORTITOR, Inscr. Mur. 984, 1.—</sense><sense id="n30558.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a ship-master</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">functio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> </sense><sense id="n30558.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a ship-owner</hi> who hires out vessels for money, <hi rend="ital">a ship-master</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 9, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 3, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">naviculariis nostris injuriosius tractatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 5, 11</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">mercatores, navicularii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:55:section=137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 55, § 137</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 55</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30558.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the business of one who hired out small vessels for transporting passengers and goods, the shipping business</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">naviculariam facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:18:section=46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 18, § 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naviculor: <entryFree id="n30559" type="main" key="na_vi^cu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭcŭlor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">naucŭlor</orth>), <itype>āri</itype>, <sense id="n30559.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. dep. n.</hi> [navicula], <hi rend="ital">to sail in a small vessel</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lucrino nauculatur in stagno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:20:20" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 20, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
navifragus: <entryFree id="n30560" type="main" key="na_vi^fra^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭfrăgus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navis-frango</etym>, <sense id="n30560.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">causing shipwrecks, dangerous</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">navifragum Scylaceum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:553" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 553</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fretum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saxa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:415" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 415</bibl></cit>; cf. naufragus, I. B.</sense></entryFree>
navigabilis: <entryFree id="n30561" type="main" key="na_vi^ga_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navigo</etym>, <sense id="n30561.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">navigable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fossa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">litora,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flumen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:2:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: fontes magnorum fluminum, Auct. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:76" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 76</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
navigatio: <entryFree id="n30562" type="main" key="na_vi^ga_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30562.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sailing, navigation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex tuis litteris cognovi cursūs navigationum tuarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:68:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 68, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in portum ex longā navigatione venire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:19:71" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 19, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prima navigatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 6, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigationi se committere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">celeri navigatione properare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 81</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">maris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diei navigatione distare,</quote> <trans><tr>a day's sail</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 75, 77, § 187</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aegyptia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 6, 19, § 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
navigator: <entryFree id="n30563" type="main" key="na_vi^ga_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n30563.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sailor, mariner</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:27" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 27</bibl>; Auct. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Deel. 12:23" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Deel. 12, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> ad Cyther. 397</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naviger: <entryFree id="n30564" type="main" key="na_vi^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭger</orth>, <itype>ĕra, ĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>navis-gero</etym>. <sense id="n30564.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Ship-bearing, navigable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare navigerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:99:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 99, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30564.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Sailing</hi>: navigera similitudo, <hi rend="ital">the likeness of a vessel under sail;</hi> said of a sea-mussel, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 30, 49, § 94</bibl>; v. nauplius.</sense></entryFree>
navigiolum: <entryFree id="n30565" type="main" key="na_vi^gi^o^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgĭŏlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>navigium</etym>, <sense id="n30565.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small vessel, a bark. boat</hi>, Lentul. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 15, 2</bibl>; Auct. Bell. Al. 63, 2.</sense></entryFree>
navigium: <entryFree id="n30566" type="main" key="na_vi^gi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>navigo</etym>, <sense id="n30566.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a vessel, a ship, bark, boat</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30566.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">navigia facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:60:152" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 60, 152</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigium dissolutum, vel potius dissipatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:11:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 15, 11, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">probum navigium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 31, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luculentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eodem velut navigio participem esse periculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deucalion navigio montem ascendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:82" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 82</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30566.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30566.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A float, raft</hi> (post-class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:12:1:section=14" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 43, 12, 1, § 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30566.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A sailing, navigation</hi> (ante- and post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">in omnes navigii dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:45:1:122" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 45, 1, 122</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:12:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 43, 12, 1</bibl> <hi rend="ital">med</hi> (but not <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1006" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1006</bibl>; v. Lachm. and Munro ad loc.). <cb n="NAVI" /></sense></entryFree>
navigo: <entryFree id="n30567" type="main" key="na_vi^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭgo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>navisago</etym>, <sense id="n30567.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sail, set sail</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30567.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30567.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum per anni tempus navigare poteris, ad nos veni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex Asiā in Macedoniam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 14, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syracusas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:34:83" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 34, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in alto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51:153" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 51, 153</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plenissimis velis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:10:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 10, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nactus idoneam tempestatem ad navigandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">e portu,</quote> <trans><tr>to set sail</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:42" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 2, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo tempore ceteri praetores consueverunt navigare,</quote> <trans><tr>to go by sea</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:31:section=80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 31, § 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neve naviges, nisi explorate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 8, 1</bibl></cit>.—Of ships: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum ista classis navigārit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 14, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">decrevimus, ut classis in Italiam navigaret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 10</bibl>.—Of goods or freight: <cit><quote lang="la">interest utrum ipsae merces periculo creditoris navigent,</quote> <trans><tr>go, are transported by ship</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:2:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 22, 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">navigare in portu,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to be in safety</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 1, 22</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30567.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Act., to sail over, navigate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Xerxes maria ambulavisset, terramque navigāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:34:112" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 34, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tyrrhenum aequor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequor Ionium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Oceanum septentrionalem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 1</bibl></cit>: quae homines arant, navigant, aedificant, virtuti omnia parent, <hi rend="ital">all their achievements in navigation</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 2, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30567.4" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">totus hodie navigatur occidens: septentrionalis vero Oceanus magnā ex parte navigatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 67, 67, § 167</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:104" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 15, 24, § 104</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 34</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:28" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 28</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n30567.5" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">iis enim ventis istim navigatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si valebis, cum recte navigari poterit, tum naviges,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 12, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 26, 30, § 126</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30567.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30567.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To sail, remove, proceed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam celeriter belli impetus navigavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:12:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 12, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Africam navigabat bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:2:17" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 2, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:8:1" default="NO">2, 8, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30567.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To swim</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:19:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 19, 47</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n30567.9" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To flow</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in ipso rapidum mare navigat ore,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 5, 583</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
navis: <entryFree id="n30568" type="main" key="na_vis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<sense id="n30568.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acc. sing.</hi> usually navem, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 101</bibl> P.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:38:174" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 38, 174</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:39:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 39, 2</bibl> et saep.; <cit><quote lang="la">but navim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:22:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 22, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 25:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 25, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:32:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 32, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 114</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2</bibl> (3), 22, 41; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:663" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 663</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 218</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:34:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 34, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:141" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:98" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 98</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 2, 7, 12 al.</bibl>; <case>abl.</case> navi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:40:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 40, 159</bibl> et saep.; <cit><quote lang="la">but nave,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:42:124" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 42, 124</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:25:section=64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 25, § 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:31:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 10, 31, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:32:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 32, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 84</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 188</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">487</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 200</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:8:6" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 8, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:13:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 13, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 28, 2</bibl> et saep.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 33</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 1, p. 283</bibl> P.; v. Neue, Formenl. 1, p. 200 sq.; 216 sq.), <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">nau=s</foreign>; Sanscr. nau, the same</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a ship</hi> (syn.: navigium). </sense><sense id="n30568.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">navis longa,</quote> <trans><tr>a ship of war</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oneraria,</quote> <trans><tr>a transport</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mercatoria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">praedatoria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 3, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praetoria,</quote> <trans><tr>the admiral's ship</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 29, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tecta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 22, 21</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">or, constrata,</quote> <trans><tr>having a deck, decked</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 35, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperta,</quote> <trans><tr>open, without a deck</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 32, 21</bibl></cit>: auri navem evertat gubernator, an paleae, <hi rend="ital">laden with gold</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chaff</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:3:1:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 3, 1, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem construere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:20:72" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 20, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">triremis instar aedificata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:17:section=44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 17, § 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem adornare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">armare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reficere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fabricari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deducere,</quote> <trans><tr>to launch</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deducere in aquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moliri ab terrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex portu educere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subducere in aridum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agere,</quote> <trans><tr>to work a ship</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mercibus implere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:288" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 288</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solvere,</quote> <trans><tr>to set sail</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 6</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">naves leni vento solverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 4, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea Hodie solutast navis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 3, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem appellere ad aliquem locum,</quote> <trans><tr>to land</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">applicare terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">appellere litori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:2:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem fregit,</quote> <trans><tr>was shipwrecked, cast away</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in portu evertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:38:174" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 38, 174</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impingere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:61" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deprimere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gubernare et salvam in portu collocare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 9, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">remis incitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in navibus vehi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:37:89" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N.
