D. 3, 37, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">e navi egredi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Vatin. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lassus sum hercle e navi,</quote> <trans><tr>from my voyage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 173</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navis cursum suum tenens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:39:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 39, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem statuere,</quote> <trans><tr>to heave to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navium tutela,</quote> <trans><tr>the image of a deity placed on the stern of the vessel, under whose protection the ship was placed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:10:1" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 16, 112</bibl>; <cb n="NAVU" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:301" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 301</bibl>. The proper badge of a vessel, after which it was named, was placed on the prow: Aeneia puppis Prima tenet rostro Phrygios subjuncta leones. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 157</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 116</bibl> sq.: <cit><quote lang="la">TRIREME MARTE, Inscr. Mur. 780, 5.—Prov.: navibus atque quadrigis petere aliquid,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>with all one's power, with might and main</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 28</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:131" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 131</bibl>: navem perforare quā ipse quis naviget, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to do one's self an injury</hi>, Cic. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 47</bibl>: navem mortuo applicare, <hi rend="ital">to rescue a drowned man from the water</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to bring assistance when too late</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 12:23" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 12, 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30568.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n30568.3" n="1" level="3"> = pudenda muliebria, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 2, 3, 51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 24</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30568.4" n="2" level="3"> Navis Argolica, or simply Navis, <hi rend="ital">the ship</hi> Argo, <hi rend="ital">placed among the constellations</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,060:chapter=277" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Arat. 277</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30568.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of political affairs: <cit><quote lang="la">una navis est jam bonorum omnium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:25:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 25, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navis rei publicae fluctuans in alto tempestatibus seditionum ac discordiarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:20:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 20, 46</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
navisalvia: <entryFree id="n30569" type="gloss" key="Na_vi^salvi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāvĭsalvĭa</orth> (sc. dea), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30569.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name under which divine honors were paid at Rome, in the vestibule of the temple of the</hi> Deum Mater, <hi rend="ital">to the vestal Claudia Quinta, who, in the year of Rome</hi> 549, <hi rend="ital">drew up the Tiber the ship which brought the image of Cybele from Pessinus to Rome</hi> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:8:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 8, 11</bibl>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1905</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1906</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2403</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
navita: <entryFree id="n30570" type="main" key="na_vi^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭta</orth>, v. nauta.</entryFree>
navitas: <entryFree id="n30571" type="main" key="na_vi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭtas</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">gnāv-</orth>), <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>navus</etym>, <sense id="n30571.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">promptness, assiduity, zeal</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">istam operam tuam, navitatem, animum in rem publicam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:25:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 25, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gnavitas studiosa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 1, p. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naviter: <entryFree id="n30572" type="main" key="na_vi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. navus <sense id="n30572.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> B.</sense></entryFree>
navities: <entryFree id="n30573" type="gloss" key="na_vi^ti^es"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭtĭes</orth>, <itype>ēi</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>navus</etym>, <sense id="n30573.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">diligence, zeal</hi>: navities, <foreign lang="greek">a)reth/</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
navius: <entryFree id="n30574" type="main" key="Navi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Navĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n30574.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman proper name</hi>. Especially celebrated is Attus Navius, <hi rend="ital">an augur under Tarquinius Priscus, who cut a stone in two with a razor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:3:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:17:31 sq" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 17, 31 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 18, 20, § 77</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Navĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Navian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Navia ficus,</quote> <trans><tr>a fig-tree in the Comitium at Rome, on the spot where Navius cut the stone in two with a razor. As long as it flourished Roman liberty was to endure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 18, 20, § 77</bibl></cit>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
navo: <entryFree id="n30575" type="main" key="na_vo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>navus</etym>, <sense id="n30575.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to do, perform</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">accomplish</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">with zeal and diligence</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">nemo est tam afflictus, quin possit navare aliquid et efficere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 1, 7</bibl></cit>: navare operam alicui, <hi rend="ital">to come to one's assistance, to serve</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assist one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utinam potuissem tibi operam meam studiumque navare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">operam rei publicae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 25, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:17:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 17, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam mihi videor navāsse operam, quod huc venerim,</quote> <trans><tr>to have succeeded in my endeavors</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortiter in acie navare operam,</quote> <trans><tr>to act vigorously</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:35" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">navandae operae avidior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 42</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">for which: opus navare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:144" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam vellem Bruto studium tuum navare potuisses!</quote> <trans><tr>to show, exhibit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 4, 5</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">si suffragandi studia non navant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. Cic. Petit. Cons. 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">benevolentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum,</quote> <trans><tr>to prosecute vigorously</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flagitium,</quote> <trans><tr>to commit, perpetrate</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem publicam,</quote> <trans><tr>to serve the state</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 2, 5</bibl></cit> (dub.; B. and K. gubernare).—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">nā-vanter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">with zeal</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 2, 23 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
navus: <entryFree id="n30576" type="main" key="na_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">gnāvus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. gnā, know; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">gignw/skw</foreign>; cf. Lat. notus, gnarus; for signif. cf. Germ. kennen and können</etym>, <sense id="n30576.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">busy, diligent, assiduous, active</hi> (syn.: impiger, industrius, sedulus; class.): navus repertus homo, Enn. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169</bibl> Müll. (Ann. v. 183 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">homo gnavus et industrius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:21:section=53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 21, § 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 7, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aratores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:51:section=120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 51, § 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">filius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 69</bibl></cit>. § <cit><quote lang="la">161: vir gnavus, agilis, providus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:105:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 105, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rudimenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:549" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 549</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timor,</quote> <trans><tr>that renders industrious</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:349" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 349</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in inquirendis gnaviores quam in componendis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 26, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostium naviores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Res Gest. Alex. 1:41" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Res Gest. Alex. 1, 41</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>, in two forms. *</sense><sense id="n30576.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">gnāvē</orth>), <hi rend="ital">diligently, actively, zealously</hi> (ante-class.): nave agere oportet quod agas, non ductarier, Plaut. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=169" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 169</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 77:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 77, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30576.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">nāvĭter</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">gnāvĭter</orth>; class.). </sense><sense id="n30576.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Diligently, actively,<pb n="1193" /> <cb n="NE" />  zealously</hi>: bene naviter ire, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 185</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">naviter versari in provinciā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:4:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">expedire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 4</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n30576.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">wholly, completely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bene et naviter impudens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 12, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plenum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:525" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 525</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
naxa: <entryFree id="n30577" type="main" key="naxa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naxa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. nassa.</entryFree>
naxium: <entryFree id="n30578" type="main" key="naxi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">naxĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n30578.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a stone used for polishing marble, which was found on the island of Cyprus and prepared in the city of Naxos, in Crete</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 7, 10, § 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:109" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 8, 32, § 109</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
naxos: <entryFree id="n30579" type="main" key="Naxos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Naxos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*na/cos</foreign>, <sense id="n30579.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the isle of Naxos</hi> (now <hi rend="ital">Naxia</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">Axia</hi>), <hi rend="ital">in the Ægean Sea, the largest of the Cyclades, famed for its wines, and for the abandonment there of Ariadne by Theseus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 22, § 67</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 125</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:640" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 640</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:17" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 17</bibl> (4, 16), 27.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Naxĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Naxian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">turba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:17" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 17</bibl></cit> (4, 16), 28: <cit><quote lang="la">juncus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 18, 69, § 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardor,</quote> <trans><tr>Ariadne's crown, a constellation</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:52" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 52</bibl></cit>: cos, = <foreign lang="greek">*naci/a a)ko/nh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a whetstone from Naxos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 22, 47, § 164</bibl>. —<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">naxĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a Naxian whetstone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 7, 10, § 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:109" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 8, 32, § 109</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n30579.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An ancient city of Sicily, destroyed by Dionysius. On or near its site Tauromenium was built</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 88</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nazaraeus: <entryFree id="n30580" type="main" key="Na_za^raeus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāzăraeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nazarai=os</foreign>, <sense id="n30580.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Nazarite, a man set apart to the service of God</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judic. 13, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:49:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Gen. 49, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30581" type="main" key="Naza^raeu^s2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nazăraeŭs</orth>, v. Nazareth <sense id="n30581.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
nazareth: <entryFree id="n30582" type="main" key="Na_za^reth"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāzăreth</orth>, indecl., or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nāzăra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30582.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Palestine, the home of the parents of Jesus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Matt. 2, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Nazareth potest aliquid boni esse?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Johan. 1, 46</bibl></cit>.—Form Nazara, <bibl default="NO"><author>Juvenc.</author> 2, 197</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nazărēnus, Nază-rēus</orth>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nazărus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Nazareth, Nazarene</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jesus Nazarenus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Johan. 19, 19</bibl></cit>; also, <hi rend="ital">Nazarene</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Christian</hi>: disciplina Nazarena, Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 10, 45: Nazarei viri, <hi rend="ital">Christians</hi>, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:550" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 1, 550</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nazara plebes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Juvenc.</author> 3, 29</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30582.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nazărēnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Nazarene</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Christ</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 7, 1</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n30582.2" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nazăraeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a Nazarene</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 2, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ne: <entryFree id="n30583" type="main" key="ne_1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nē</orth> (old forms nei and ni; <sense id="n30583.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr>), <pos>adv.</pos> and <hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, the primitive Latin negative particle, <hi rend="ital">no, not;</hi> whereas the negative particle non is a derivative (v. non <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>) [prob. of pronominal origin; cf. the Anglo-Saxon na and ne (Engl. no), whence naht (Engl. not) is derived; Sanscr. na, not]. </sense><sense id="n30583.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>, with a single word of a proposition (in early Latin): NE MINVS TRINVM NOVNDINVM, <hi rend="ital">not less than</hi>, etc., S. C. de Bacch.; cf. with DVM NE MINVS SENATORIBVS C. ADESENT, twice in the same S. C.; <cit><quote lang="la">and in the form ni: DVM NI MINVS VIGINTI ADSIENT,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 207, 3</bibl></cit>. So too: <cit><quote lang="la">DVM NE AMPLIOREM MODVM PRATORVM HABEANT QVAM, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3121</bibl></cit> (Sententia de finibus inter Genuates et Viturios regundis lata A. U. C. 637). So, ne minores (verres) quam semestres, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:4:21" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 4, 21</bibl>. In the time of Plautus the usage was unsettled, <hi rend="ital">non</hi> and <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> being used indifferently for simple negation; cf. Lorenz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 105</bibl>; Brix ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1156</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.2" n="2" level="3"> To this is allied the adverbial use of <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> in all periods of the language. </sense><sense id="n30583.3" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ne ... quidem</hi>, applies the negation with emphasis to the word between them, <hi rend="ital">not even</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sues quidem id velint, non modo ipse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:38:92" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 38, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in oppidis quidem ... ne in fanis quidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:1:section=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 1, § 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Philippus non item: itaque ne nos quidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla ne minima quidem aura fluctus commovente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:6:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 6, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non potest dici satis, ne cogitari quidem, quantum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:29:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 29, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita beata, quam ne in deo quidem esse censes, nisi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:24:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 24, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut in foro et in judicio ... ne non timere quidem sine aliquo timore possimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne tondere quidem Vellera possunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:561" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 561</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so after a negative, repeating it with emphasis: non enim praetereundum est ne id quidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:60:section=155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 60, § 155</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla species ne excogitari quidem potest ornatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:45:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 45, 179</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non praetermittam ne illud quidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar negat se ne Graeca quidem meliora legisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 16, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam illum ne minima quidem re offendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:103" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 27, 103</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28</bibl>, <cb n="NE" /> 42, 16; but when <hi rend="ital">ne ... quidem</hi> precedes, the negative of the principal verb is omitted: <cit><quote lang="la">sine quā ne intellegi quidem ulla virtus potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:13:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 13, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque enim ipsius quidem regis abhorrebat animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:12:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 12, 10</bibl></cit>: ne quidem (with no intervening word), <hi rend="ital">not even</hi> (late Lat.), Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 1, 67</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 93</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.4" n="b" level="4"> In composition, to make an absolute negation of the principal idea. So in <hi rend="ital">neque</hi> and <hi rend="ital">nequiquam;</hi> also in <hi rend="ital">nescio</hi> and <hi rend="ital">nevolo;</hi> and in <hi rend="ital">nefas, nefandus, nepus</hi> (for non purus), <hi rend="ital">nequeo, neuter, neutiquam;</hi> in <hi rend="ital">nemo, nego, nihil, nullus, numquam</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">nusquam;</hi> and, lastly, with a paragogic <hi rend="ital">c</hi> before <hi rend="ital">o</hi>: necopinans and neglego; negotium (i. e. nec-lego; nec-otium). —</sense><sense id="n30583.5" n="B" level="2"> With a proposition (in all periods of the language, and exclusively), </sense><sense id="n30583.6" n="1" level="3"> In imperative sentences, to signify that something must not be done. </sense><sense id="n30583.7" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi>: SI HOMINEM FVLMEN IOVIS OCCISIT, NE SVPRA GENVA TOLLITOR, <hi rend="ital">let him not be raised</hi>, Leg. Reg.: HOMINEM MORTVVM IN VRBE NE SEPELITO NEVE VRITO, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 23</bibl>; cf.: MVLIERES GENAS NE RADVNTO NEVE LESSVM FVNERIS ERGO HABENTO, ib.: SI NOLET, ARCERAM NE STERNITO, <hi rend="ital">let him not spread, he need not spread</hi>, ib. (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1:25" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1, 25</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">VECTIGAL INVITEI DARE NEI DEBENTO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3121</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">art. ni, II.: abi, ne jura: satis credo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 3, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 5, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, ne saevi tantopere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impius ne audeto placare donis iram deorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:9:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 9, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne, pueri, ne tanta animis assuescite bella,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:832" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 832</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n30583.8" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne me moveatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si certum est facere, facias: verum ne post conferas Culpam in me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si denique veritas extorquebit, ne repugnetis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne pudori Sit tibi Musa lyrae sollers,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:406" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 406</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.9" n="2" level="3"> In wishes and asseverations: ne id Juppiter Opt. Max. sineret, etc., <hi rend="ital">might Jupiter forbid it!</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 2</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ne istuc Juppiter Opt. Max. sirit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 28</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">utinam</hi>: utinam ne in nemore Pelio securibus Caesa accedisset abiegna ad terram trabes, <hi rend="ital">would that not</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:16:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 16, 61</bibl> (Trag. v. 280 Vahl.): utinam ne umquam, Mede Colchis cupido corde pedem extulisses, Enn ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 297, 18</bibl> (Trag. v. 311 ib.): <cit><quote lang="la">illud utinam ne vere scriberem!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:17:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 17, 3</bibl></cit>; v. utinam.—With <hi rend="ital">si</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne vivam, si scio,</quote> <trans><tr>may I not live, may I die, if I know</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 16, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed ne vivam, si tibi concedo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:23:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 23, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sim salvus, si aliter scribo ac sentio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 13, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.10" n="3" level="3"> In concessive and restrictive clauses (conceived as softened commands; cf. II. <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>). </sense><sense id="n30583.11" n="(a)" level="5"> In concessions, nemo is, inquies, umquam fuit. Ne fuerit: <cit><quote lang="la">ego enim, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>there may not have been; suppose there was not</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:29:101" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 29, 101</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnes omnino, sed cum adversario facili. Ne sit sane: videri certe potest,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 26, 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 32, 102</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sit sane summum malum dolor: malum certe est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:5:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 5, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sint in senectute vires: ne postulantur quidem vires a senectute,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:11:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 11, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sit igitur sol, ne luna, ne stellae, quoniam nihil esse potest, nisi quod attigimus aut vidimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:31:88" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 31, 88</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec porro malum, quo aut oppressus jaceas, aut, ne opprimare, mente vix constes?</quote> <trans><tr>though you be not crushed; supposing you are not crushed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:17:39" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 17, 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.12" n="(b)" level="5"> In restrictive clauses: <cit><quote lang="la">sint sane liberales ex sociorum fortunis, sint misericordes in furibus aerarii, ne illi sanguinem nostrum largiantur, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>only let them not; if they only will not</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 12</bibl></cit>. So, dum ne, dummodo ne, modo ne, and dum quidem ne; v. dum and modo: me vero nihil istorum ne juvenem quidem movit umquam: ne nunc senem, <hi rend="ital">much less now I am old</hi> = nedum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:26:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 26, 2</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">vix incedo inanis, ne ire posse cum onere existumes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:174" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 174</bibl></cit>: scuta si homines inviti dant, etsi ad salutem communem dari sentiunt: ne quem putetis sine maximo dolore argentum caelatum domo protulisse, <hi rend="ital">much less can you suppose</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:23:section=52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 23, § 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 52</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.13" n="4" level="3"> In clauses which denote a purpose or result. </sense><sense id="n30583.14" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ut ne, that not, lest, so that not</hi> (very rare after the August. period; in Livy only in a few doubtful passages; in Cæsar, Seneca, and Tacitus not at all; v. under II.): quos ego ope meā Pro incertis certos ... Dimitto, ut ne res temere tractent turbidas, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:45:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 45, 199</bibl> (Trag v. 189 Vahl.): <cb n="NE" /> vestem ut ne inquinet, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 17</bibl>. pergunt turbare usque, ut ne quid possit conquiescere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec mihi nunc cura est maxima, ut ne cui meae Longinquitas aetatis obstet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego, pol, te ulciscar, ut ne impune nos illuseris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 4, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">excitandam esse animadversionem et diligentiam, ut ne quid inconsiderate negligenterque agamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:29:103" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 29, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equidem soleo dare operam, ut de suā quisque re me ipse doceat, et, ut ne quis alius assit, quo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:24:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 24, 102</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n30583.15" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Ut ... ne</hi> separated: <cit><quote lang="la">quam plurimis de rebus ad me velim scribas, ut prorsus ne quid ignorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut causae communi salutique ne deessent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:63:section=140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 63, § 140</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lata lex est, ne auspicia valerent, ut omnibus fastis diebus legem ferri liceret: ut lex Aelia, lex Fufia ne valeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:15:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 15, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:7:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 7, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos orant atque obsecrant, judices, ut in actore causae suae deligendo vestrum judicium ab suo judicio ne discrepet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Div. in Caecil. 4, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.16" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Qui ne, quo ne</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">quomodo ne</hi> (ante- and post-class. for ut ne): <cit><quote lang="la">ego id agam, mihi qui ne detur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moxque ad aram, quo ne hostis dolum persentisceret, aversusque a duce assistit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Dict. Cret.</author> 4, 11</bibl></cit>: quaeritis maximis sumptibus faciendis, quomodo ne tributa conferatis, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">w(s mh/</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0425,001:1:9" default="NO"><author>Rutil. Lup.</author> 1, 9</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n30583.17" n="II" level="1"> In the several uses of the <hi rend="ital">adv. ne</hi>, described above, the transition to its use to connect clauses is clearly seen (v. esp. I. B. 3. and 4.). In intentional clauses, and after verbs of fearing and avoiding, <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> becomes a conjunction. </sense><sense id="n30583.18" n="A" level="2"> In intentional clauses for <hi rend="ital">ut ne, that not, lest</hi>: nolite, hospites, ad me adire: ilico isti! Ne contagio mea bonis umbrave obsit, <hi rend="ital">approach me not; let not my presence harm you</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">lest my presence should harm you</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:12:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 12, 26</bibl> (Trag. v. 405 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">omitto innumerabiles viros, quorum singuli saluti huic civitati fuerunt ... ne quis se aut suorum aliquem praetermissum queratur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 7, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 5, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesarem complexus obsecrare coepit, ne quid gravius in fratrem statueret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 20</bibl></cit>.—Esp. after verbs expressing <hi rend="ital">forethought, care</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">vide sis, ne quid imprudens ruas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">considera, ne in alienissimum tempus cadat adventus tuus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:14:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cocceius, vide, ne frustretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 18, 3</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n30583.19" n="B" level="2"> After verbs signifying <hi rend="ital">to fear, frighten</hi>, etc. (esp. metuo, timeo, vereor, horreo, paveo, terreo, conterreo; also, timor est, metus est, spes est, periculum est), to express the wish that something may not take place; represented in English by <hi rend="ital">that</hi> (because in English the particle depends on the idea of fearing, not of wishing): <cit><quote lang="la">metuo et timeo, ne hoc tandem propalam flat,</quote> <trans><tr>that it will be discovered</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:8:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 8, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timeo ne malefacta mea sint inventa omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vereor ne quid Andria apportet mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuebat ne indicarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:21:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 21, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mater cruciatur et sollicita est, ne filium spoliatum omni dignitate conspiciat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:41:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 41, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic ne quid mihi prorogetur, horreo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id paves, ne ducas tu illam, tu autem ut ducas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">esse metus coepit, ne, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:715" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 715</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terruit gentīs, grave ne rediret Saeculum Pyrrhae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non periclumst, nequid recte monstres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pavor ceperat milites, ne mortiferum esset vulnus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 42</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n30583.20" n="b" level="4"> When the dependent clause is negative, with <hi rend="ital">non</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nihil, that not</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vereor ne exercitum firmum habere non possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unum vereor ne senatus Pompeium nolit dimittere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 18, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timeo ne non impetrem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 6, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:31:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 31, 76</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.21" n="c" level="4"> With the negative before the verb: <cit><quote lang="la">non vereor, ne quid temere facias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">timere non debeo, ne non iste illā cruce dignus judicetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:67:section=171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 67, § 171</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30583.22" n="C" level="2"> After verbs signifying <hi rend="ital">to avoid, warn, hinder, forbid, refuse</hi> (caveo, impedio, resisto, interdico, refuto, rarely veto), instead of the simple object, <hi rend="ital">that not, lest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui cavet, ne decipiatur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cavete, judices, ne nova proscriptio instaurata esse videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:53:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 53, 153</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:12:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 12, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. caveo: casus quidam ne facerem impedivit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unus ne caperetur urbs causa fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 39</bibl></cit>. <pb n="1194" /> <cb n="NE" /></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30584" type="main" key="ne^2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">-nĕ</orth> (also apocopated <orth extent="full" lang="la">n'</orth> and only <orth extent="full" lang="la">n</orth>), <sense id="n30584.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">interrog.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">enclit. part.</hi> [weakened from nē]. It simply inquires, without implying either that a negative or an affirmative reply is expected (cf. num, nonne), and emphasizes the word to which it is joined; <cit><quote lang="la">which is always, in classic Latin, the first word of the clause (ante- class. after other words: sine dote uxoremne?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 94</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 2, 78</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 92</bibl>). In direct questions it is translated by giving an interrogative form to the sentence; in indirect interrogations by <hi rend="ital">whether</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30584.1" n="(a)" level="5"> In direct interrogations, with <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meministine me in senatu dicere? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potestne rerum major esse dissensio?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:13:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 13, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tune id veritus es?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamne vides, belua, jamne sentis? etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid, si etiam falsum illud omnino est? tamenne ista tam absurda defendes?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:29:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 29, 81</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:15:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 15, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quiane auxilio juvat ante levatos?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:538" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 538</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tun' te audes Sosiam esse dicere?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 217</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valuistin?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 12</bibl></cit>.—After an elided <hi rend="ital">s</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">satin habes, si feminarum nulla'st: quam aeque diligam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pergin autem?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vin commutemus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:21 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 21 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n30584.2" n="(b)" level="5"> Esp. with <hi rend="ital">rel. pron.; ellipt.</hi>: quemne ego servavi? i. e. <hi rend="ital">do you mean the one whom?</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:1:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 1, 1, 13</bibl>: quodne vobis placeat, displiceat mihi? <hi rend="ital">can it be that what pleases?</hi> etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 3, 3, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 2, 65</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so quin for quine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 79</bibl></cit> Brix ad loc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:50 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 2, 50 al.</bibl>—So with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> and <hi rend="ital">si</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utine adveniens vomitum excutias mulieri?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 3, 3, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin, saluti quod tibi esse censeo, id. consuadeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:1:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 1, 2, 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30584.3" n="(g)" level="5"> In indirect interrogations, with <hi rend="ital">subj., whether</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut videamus, satisne ista sit justa defectio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 12, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Publilius iturusne sit in Africam et quando, ex Aledio scire poteris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:24:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 24, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">videto vasa, multane sient,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem imitari possimusne, ipse liber erit indicio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 4</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10</bibl>, § 9.—</sense><sense id="n30584.4" n="(d)" level="5"> Sometimes affixed to an interrogative pronoun, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 4, 1, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quone malo mentem concussa? Timore deorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:295" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 295</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">uterne Ad casus dubios fidet sibi certius?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 107</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">illa rogare: Quantane?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 317</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">-ne</hi> is sometimes used for <hi rend="ital">nonne</hi>, where an affirmative reply is expected: <cit><quote lang="la">misine ego ad te epistulam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 6, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 92</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">rectene interpretor sententiam tuam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:17:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 17, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:32:104" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 32, 104</bibl>.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) Rarely = num: <cit><quote lang="la">potestne virtus servire?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:52:226" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 52, 226</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potesne dicere?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:27:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 27, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16, 56</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30584.5" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">an, annon</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">anne</hi>, in the second interrogation, v. an.—With <hi rend="ital">necne</hi>, v. neque.—Sometimes pleonastic with utrum, followed by an (mostly anteclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">est etiam illa distinctio, utrum illudne non videatur aegre ferendum ... an, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:27:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 27, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed utrum strictimne attonsurum dicam esse an per pectinem, nescio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 18</bibl></cit> Brix ad loc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:151" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 151</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 42</bibl>; cf. Madv. Gram. § 452, obs. 1.—Sometimes, in the second interrogation, <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> for <hi rend="ital">an</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">Smyrna quid et Colophon? Majora minorane fama?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut in incerto fuerit, vicissent victine essent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:28:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 28, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum interrogaretur, utrum pluris patrem matremne faceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Iphicr. 3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iphicr. 3, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30585" type="main" key="ne_3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nē</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos> (incorrectly written <orth extent="full" lang="la">nae</orth>), = <foreign lang="greek">nai/, nh/</foreign>, <sense id="n30585.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">truly, verily, really, indeed</hi> (only joined with <hi rend="ital">pers. pron.</hi> ego, tu, and with the <hi rend="ital">demonstratives</hi> ille, iste, hic, and their <hi rend="ital">advv.;</hi> in class, prose usually with a conditional clause). </sense><sense id="n30585.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ego homo infelix fui, Qui non alas intervelli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 169</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ego haud paulo hunc animum malim quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:42:99" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 42, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ego, inquam, si ita est, velim tibi eum placere quam maxime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:71:249" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 71, 249</bibl></cit>. So, ne tu, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 6, 15</bibl>: ne ille, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 73, 18</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 9 v. 40 Rib.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 3, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne iste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 1, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:1:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 1, 8 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n30585.2" n="II" level="1"> Connected with other affirmative particles, as <hi rend="ital">hercle, edepol, mecastor, medius fidius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne tu hercle,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 4, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 38</bibl>: <cb n="NEBU" /> ne ille hercle, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 76</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">edepol ne ego,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">edepol ne tu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ista edepol,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:213" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 2, 213</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne istuc mecastor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 1, 34</bibl></cit> (729 Ritschl): <cit><quote lang="la">ne ille, medius fidius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:30:74" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 30, 74</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">medius fidius ne tu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:4:6:section=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 4, 6, § 2</bibl></cit>.— Rarely with a <hi rend="ital">pron. poss.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">edepol ne meam operam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 1</bibl></cit>. (All passages in which <hi rend="ital">ne</hi> stands in classic prose without a pronoun are probably corrupt; cf. Haase in Reisig's Vorles. p. 379 sq.; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:31:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 31, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes">34, 4, 16</bibl> Weissenb.)</sense></entryFree>
neaera: <entryFree id="n30586" type="main" key="Ne^aera"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕaera</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ne/aira</foreign>, <sense id="n30586.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a female proper name</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30586.1" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The mistress of Lygdamus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:1:6" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 1, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:23" default="NO">23</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n30586.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A mistress of Horace</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:14:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 14, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 15</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n30586.3" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A mistress of the shepherd Ægon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30586.4" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Iole, the mistress of Hercules</hi>, Prud. <foreign lang="greek">stef</foreign>. 10, 240.—</sense><sense id="n30586.5" n="5" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Ariadne, as the mistress of Bacchus</hi>, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:139" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 1, 139</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
neaethus: <entryFree id="n30587" type="main" key="Ne^aethus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕaethus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ne/aiqos</foreign>, <sense id="n30587.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in the territory of the Bruttii</hi>, the modern <hi rend="ital">Nieto</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Neto</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 15, § 97</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 51</bibl>, instead of Neaethum, we should read, acc. to the manuscripts, Neretum, q. v.).</sense></entryFree>
neaniscologus: <entryFree id="n30588" type="greek" key="ne^a_nisco^lo^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕāniscŏlŏgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">neaniskolo/gos</foreign>, <sense id="n30588.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">speaking in a juvenile manner</hi>, Schol. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:191" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 191</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
neapolis: <entryFree id="n30589" type="main" key="Ne^a_po^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕāpŏlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nea/polis</foreign> (Newtown). <sense id="n30589.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A celebrated maritime city in Campania, a colony of the Cumæans, called by the early Romans</hi> Novapolis, now <hi rend="ital">Napoli, Naples</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=58" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 58</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:24:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 24, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:10:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 10, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">otiosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:43" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">docta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:78:14" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 78, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hospita Musis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:31" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 31</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n30589.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕāpŏlītānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Naples, Neapolitan</hi>: piscinae, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 543, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 17, 26, § 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mala cotonea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 15, 11, 10, § 38</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n30589.2" n="b" level="4"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n30589.3" n="(a)" level="5"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕāpŏlītānum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a villa near Naples;</hi> of Pompey, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 2, 5</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">of Lucullus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 3, 9</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of Pontius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 14, 21, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30589.4" n="(b)" level="5"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕāpŏlītāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Neapolitans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:30:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 30, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:10:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 10, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:35:86" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 35, 86</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30589.5" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕāpŏlītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a Neapolitan</hi>: Dion, Varr. ap. Aug. Civ. Dei, 21, 8.—</sense><sense id="n30589.6" n="3" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕā-pŏlītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a</hi> (female) <hi rend="ital">Neapolitan</hi>: meretrix, Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 318, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30589.7" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city in Zeugitana</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Nabal</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 4, 3, § 24</bibl>; Auct. B. Afr. 2.—</sense><sense id="n30589.8" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The fourth quarter of the city of Syracuse</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:53:section=119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 53, § 119</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:25:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 25, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nearchus: <entryFree id="n30590" type="main" key="Ne^archus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nĕarchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ne/arxos</foreign>. <sense id="n30590.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An admiral of Alexander the Great, who commanded the fleet sent on a voyage of discovery to India, and wrote the history of the expedition</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 23, 26, § 97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:10:2" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 10, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:1:5" default="NO">10, 1, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:6:6 al" default="NO">10, 6, 6 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n30590.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Tarentine, a host of the elder Cato</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:12:41" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 12, 41</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30590.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A beautiful youth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:20:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 20, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebiodunum: <entryFree id="n30591" type="main" key="Nebiodu_num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nebiodūnum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Noviodūnum</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n30591.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Lower Mœsia</hi>, Cod. Th. 10, 21, 1.</sense></entryFree>
nebridae: <entryFree id="n30592" type="main" key="ne_^bri^dae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nē^brĭdae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nebris</etym>, <sense id="n30592.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the priests of Ceres clothed in a fawn-skin at the Eleusinian mysteries, the nebris-wearers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebridarum familia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, 185</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nebris: <entryFree id="n30593" type="greek" key="ne_^bris1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nē^bris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nebri/s</foreign>, <sense id="n30593.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fawnskin worn by the Bacchanals at the Bacchic festivals</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebridas et fragiles thyrsos portare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:664" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 664</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a tereti demisit nebrida collo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Achill. 1, 609</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Honor. 605</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30594" type="gloss" key="Nebris2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nebris</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n30594.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 476, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebritis: <entryFree id="n30595" type="greek" key="nebri_tis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nebrītis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nebri=tis</foreign>, <sense id="n30595.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a precious stone sacred to Bacchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 64, § 175</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebrodes: <entryFree id="n30596" type="main" key="Nebro_des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nebrōdes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nebrw/dh</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">*neurw/dh, ta/</foreign>, <sense id="n30596.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a chain of mountains running across Sicily from east to west</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:237" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 237</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 5, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebrophonos: <entryFree id="n30597" type="greek" key="Nebro^pho^nos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nebrŏphŏnos</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Nebrŏphŏnē</orth>, <gen>m.</gen> and <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">nebrofo/nos</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">nebrofo/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n30597.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fawnkiller</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30597.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Masc., the name of a dog</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nebrophonosque valens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 211</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30597.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem., a nymph of Diana</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Laud. Stil. 3, 249</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebrundines: <entryFree id="n30598" type="gloss" key="nebrundines"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nebrundines</orth>, v. nefrens.</entryFree>
nebrus: <entryFree id="n30599" type="gloss" key="Nebrus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Nebrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*nebro/s</foreign> (fawn), <sense id="n30599.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 476, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
nebula: <entryFree id="n30600" type="main" key="ne^bu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕbŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>like nubes; Sanscr. nabhas; Lat. aër, caelum; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">nefe/lh</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n30600.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">mist, vapor, fog, smoke, exhalation</hi> (syn.: nubes, nimbus). </sense><sense id="n30600.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: fluviis ex omnibus et <cb n="NECE" /> simul ipsa Surgere de terrā nebulas aestumque videmus, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:477" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 477</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:258" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 258</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenuem exhalat nebulam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 2, 217</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of the clouds: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulae pluviique rores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 56</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:412" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 412</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">439</bibl> (for which, nubes, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 587</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 21</bibl>. —Of smoke, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:5:31" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 5, 31</bibl>.—Of any thing soft or transparent: <cit><quote lang="la">nebula haud est mollis, atque hujus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:4:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 4, 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">desine Inter ludere virgines Et stellis nebulam spargere candidis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:15:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 15, 6</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Prov.: nebulae cyathus, of any thing worthless, trifling,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 62</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">—Personified = Nephele,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 2" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 2</bibl></cit> and 3.—</sense><sense id="n30600.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a foggy mist, a vapor, cloud</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulveris nebula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 253</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulae dolia summa tegunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:269" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 269</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pinguem nebulam vomuere lucernae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:181" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 181</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:281" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 281</bibl>: per nebulam audire, aut scire aliquid, <hi rend="ital">to hear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">know a thing indistinctly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 26</bibl> (for which: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi per caliginem videre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 2, 2</bibl></cit>).—</sense><sense id="n30600.3" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A thin, transparent substance;</hi> of a thin garment: aequum est induere nuptam ventum textilem, Palam prostare nudam in nebulā lineā, Laber. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 55</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">of a thin plate of metal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:33:3" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 33, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30600.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">darkness, obscurity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">erroris nebula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:4" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulae quaestionum,</quote> <trans><tr>obscure, puzzling questions</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:8:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 8, 10</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">in lemm.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">suspicionum nebulae,</quote> <trans><tr>vague suspicions</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 1, 4</bibl></cit>.—Of something empty, trifling, worthless: <cit><quote lang="la">grande locuturi nebulas Helicone legunto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:7" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 7</bibl></cit> (for which: <cit><quote lang="la">nubes et inania captare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:230" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 230</bibl></cit>).</sense></entryFree>
nebulo: <entryFree id="n30601" type="main" key="ne^bu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕbŭlo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>nebula</etym>, <sense id="n30601.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a paltry, worthiess fellow, an idle rascal, a sorry wretch</hi>: nugator ac nebulo, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 19, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 7, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos ab isto nebulone facetius eludimur, quam putamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:44:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 44, 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulones Alcinoique juventus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vappa ac nebulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 1, 104</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 12</bibl>: nebulo lucifugus (perh. on account of the etymology of the word), <hi rend="ital">a scoundrel that shuns the light</hi>, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 19, 2</bibl>.—In apposition with homo: <cit><quote lang="la">vulgus nebulonum hominum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:2:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:6:12" default="NO">16, 6, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n30601.1" n="II" level="1"> Acc. to Acron ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 12</bibl>, nebulo also signifies <hi rend="ital">a man of low birth;</hi> on which account slaves were also called nebulones.</sense></entryFree>
nebulor: <entryFree id="n30602" type="gloss" key="ne^bu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕbŭlor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>nebulo</etym>, <sense id="n30602.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be a worthless fellow</hi>: nebulor, <foreign lang="greek">a)xrhstw=</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
nebulositas: <entryFree id="n30603" type="main" key="ne^bu^lo_si^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕbŭlōsĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>nebulosus</etym>, <sense id="n30603.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">mistiness, cloudiness, darkness</hi> (post-class. and very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">vaporum nebulositas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, 234</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nebulosus: <entryFree id="n30604" type="main" key="ne^bu^lo_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕbŭlōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>nebula</etym>, <sense id="n30604.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of mist</hi> or <hi rend="ital">vapor, misty, foggy, cloudy, dark</hi>. </sense><sense id="n30604.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager si nebulosus est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulosum et caliginosum caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:25:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 25, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulosus et roscidus aër,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 7, 18, § 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exhalatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 31, 3, 27, § 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies nebulosi nubilive,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n30604.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. of a fine texture, <hi rend="ital">cloud-like</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">nefe/lai</foreign>, nebulosa retia, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 3, 5</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n30604.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">dark, difficult to understand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:3:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 3, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
nec: <entryFree id="n30605" type="main" key="ne^c1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕc</orth>, <sense id="n30605.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, v. neque.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n30606" type="main" key="ne^c2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">nĕc</orth>, an inseparable negative parti. cle in compounds for <sense id="n30606.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nĕ</hi>: necopinans, necopinus; also in nĕgotium for nec-otium, and in neglego for nec-lego; and with suppressed c and lengthened ē: nēquaquam, nēquiquam.</sense></entryFree>
